output: Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, the Commission appears to be acting like a distracted student who is frantically trying to make up for lost time before handing in their assignment.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be seen as a step towards the Commission addressing social issues.

The President of the Commission failed to grasp the full extent of the warning issued by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere had a popular vote been held.
These elections are calls to order.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not just to adopt even more technical directives.
Internal market regulation is indeed necessary, but it is far from being the entirety of the matter.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the commission to merely complete, or even simplify, legislation.
They await for the Commission to rise to the challenge assigned to it by the treaties, to be the locomotive, the think tank of the Union.
It is not enough for its president to be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the Council president.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in reflecting on the nature of the societal project we need.
But what is the social project outlined in this program?
The 2009 program does not contain any major errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new College to assume its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Thank you, Mr. President.

of the high-level conference on Georgia proposed by the French presidency and how the current Presidency of the Union intends to uphold Georgia's territorial integrity in light of a country recognizing two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
But it is a shame that Mr. Barroso is not here because in his speech, he was not convincing, perhaps because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he presented to us.
I believe that the financial and economic situation is far more serious than he described to us.
And even today, I believe that those who monitor the internet can see very clearly that stock markets continue to collapse despite interventions.

For me, it is the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led to land being entirely exploited and choked by greenhouse gas emissions, that resulted in misguided development in the Global South and that has led to poor urban development in our cities.
I thank the President and the Commissioner. The current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, a global response is required.
And this is particularly true in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is why we have created, among other things, the World Trade Organization, which we agree upon, and which seeks to establish globalized rules.

It turns out that it does not quite work as we would like because we are faced with a problem that is as follows. Two things must be entrusted. The free trade that is necessary and on which everyone agrees, but also the protections that are equally necessary.
And the protection of national economies or agricultures does not equate to protectionism.
To achieve this, the approach we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, is an imbalanced one that focuses on reducing tariffs with the ultimate goal of their elimination.
It turns out that, technically, reducing customs duties
It is difficult. The proof lies in a whole series of mathematical formulas: the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most well-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't work properly because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with very different rules of origin, and technically reducing customs duties is not as simple as one might think.
We find ourselves in a technical impasse and are attempting, through political negotiations, to find a way out of this deadlock.

Now, it turns out that technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology: deductible customs duty technology, which can be deducted by the exporter from the economy of the importing state.
In practice, this deductible customs duty is converted into a customs credit equal to the amount of duty the exporter has paid in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is reimbursable, negotiable, and eligible for bonuses.
It is reimbursable at the time when the exporter makes a purchase from the importer; he can deduct the customs duty he has incurred.

It is negotiable because if the exporting company, which has paid 100 in customs duties, has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates its customs credit on the stock market or with a bank.
And it is incentivizable if we want to assist developing countries, the importer, to offer an amount of customs credit greater than the amount of customs duty.
With this technique, an international trading currency is created, the monetary mass of which is equal to the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would provide 13 billion euros of international currency in the trade sector.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis provided an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the global stage as a full-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has succeeded in uniting and finding coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
In the face of crises, Europe proves its existence and demonstrates its added value.
In the realm of immigration, for instance, the every-man-for-himself approach was no longer applicable.
The adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum, initiated by the French presidency, represents a significant step forward.
In the fight against climate change, Europe must set itself concrete objectives and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish for this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently highly destabilized.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To rise to the challenges ahead, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must present us with a solution at the December European Council. Many of us are demanding it.
In recent weeks, we have proudly observed the emergence of a strong political Europe, united in adversity, resolute in the face of its partners, and listened to on the international stage.
We hope that this new European mindset will become the norm and endure.
The Lisbon Treaty is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Thank you, Madam President. Mr. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan. Of course, I pay tribute to him for acting swiftly and managing to stop the war.
But this war is somewhat our failure. For 14 years, we have been timid. We silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

And this war, certainly, has awakened Europe by placing it face to face with its responsibilities. But the fire continues to smolder in the Caucasus. And we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all Europe.
And I am also aware, Minister, of the divisions among European countries regarding Georgia's accession to NATO. Personally, I am opposed to it.
And I will make you a proposal. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasus countries.
Only the status of neutrality can ease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this subregion from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.
Mr. Prime Minister, over the last three days, the European Development Days have taken place, where there was much discussion of the food crisis that is severely affecting the poorest countries and
The interventions all emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

In passing, the lyrical pronouncements of those who called yesterday and still today for a reduction in state intervention and public spending, for across-the-board liberalization, for privatization, for the marginalization of agriculture as

This quasi-prehistoric activity, this about-face, thus in favor of massive public investments in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all of this with something at once comical and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries is directly related to the debate we are having today.

Alas, I do not feel that this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the food riots and the disastrous market turmoil, takes into account the situation of the peasantry in the Global South or fully addresses the serious ecological, social, economic, and financial risks that we face today.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between farmers in the North and South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report. The questioning of the promised one billion euros shows how much progress still needs to be made.

Thank you, Mr. President. The report we will be voting on tomorrow represents the culmination of a year's worth of work and negotiations focused on the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20th that Mrs. Fischer-Bowle came to present her proposals on the health check.
Following the report from Lutz Goebbels' tables, we now have the Capula-Santo report on the Commission's proposal.
Our two colleagues should be congratulated for their excellent work.
The Agriculture Committee of the European Parliament managed to remain firm in the face of the Commission's initial proposals, which we deemed far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant with regard to the dairy sector and in particular the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.
I am particularly thinking of mountain milk producers, who must not become the poor relations of this reform. Care must be taken not to overlook them, as they will need greater support than others.
I do not wish to play the role of Cassandra, but how can one envision the French dairy industry consolidated within a single region?
It is therefore with kindness that I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund and the one to assess, as early as 2010, the increase in milk quotas according to market developments.

The calculation of the progressive modulation carried out by the Agriculture Commission seems fair to me. It would allow us to enhance territorial development, rural areas, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also commend the clarification of eco-conditionality, whose implementation had been a real puzzle for farmers up until now.

I also hope that we maintain the tobacco fund amount that allows us to keep our small holdings and a not insignificant workforce in Europe, in a region where nothing else can be exploited, and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated a great deal of patience and determination, and you have not hesitated to invest your time without compromise.
It was a true pleasure to work alongside you.
You will have been of great help to us.
I know we can count on you.
First of all, thank you for the work accomplished and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the health check of the CAP in Mr. Caboulos-Santos' report.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond solely to market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also, all too often, on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a severe blow to our agriculture.

Decoupling, for instance, poses a real challenge for certain livestock-rearing territories, such as those with suckler cows and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Mrs Fischer-Boll address this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that strictly adhering to historical references would impose a significant constraint on any possibility of reform.

However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) is essential, as rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the countryside.
So we must reflect on this issue of the second foot without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouyens is about to leave us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have known.
I wish him good luck.

If, Madam President, I voted for the Perriche report on the integration of OCM20 into former Munich, I must say so with a heavy heart because I believe that this single OCM does not simplify matters and does not increase transparency.
It will complicate life for grape growers and the entire wine industry.
Last night, the commissioner tried to reassure us.
I hope that the Commission keeps its word and, above all, that the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first OCM 20.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project presented to us by the Commission last June.

Certainly, as early as the 2000s, initiatives were launched targeting SMEs, and I particularly think of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Blasto on the SME charter. Initiatives that were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they often remained mere pious hopes.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are going through, with consequences that are particularly worrying for SMEs, prompts us to do so if nothing else.
In this regard, the Small Business Act represents a new, decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will be examining Mrs Herzog's report on the Commission's communication. But today, through the submission of this oral question, we have sought to call on the Council.
Mr. Minister, we have noted with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know if the European Council, as early as December 11th and 12th next,
will duly relay its conclusions and give a strong impetus to ensure that the overarching principle of "thinking small first" is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan, which is annexed with a view to concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time allotted to me, I will emphasize three areas in which we need binding impulses.
impact assessments, which should be systematic, and regular monitoring with oversight by the European Parliament of the implementation status of the Small Business Act in the Member States,
access to public markets
The code of good conduct has no binding effect. Together, we need to be more imaginative and inventive, and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open up these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more essential than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are sound, Minister. They must also incorporate support for the supply side.
there is an urgent need
Thank you for assuring us of the Council's willingness.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union as they employ over 70% of the EU's workforce and account for 99% of European businesses.

But, as has already been stated, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now concerned and threatened by the financial crisis because it erodes purchasing power and household confidence, affecting order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is essential to ensure support for their activities by making sure that banks guarantee effective access to the financing needed to maintain their operations.
The entire focus is on the conclusions of the Competitiveness Council on December 1st, which the Minister mentioned, and the recovery plan approved by the European finance ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential. And I would like to commend the action plan in support of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It indeed translates the will to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle, to give priority to the smallest first, that is, to European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner stated, and as we all say, the Council must truly engage with the other European institutions.
European. For this principle to now become effective, it is necessary to go beyond the declaration, to move towards implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wished to commend, Mr. Minister, the determination of the French presidency of the Union, which enabled the rapid translation of intentions into actions.

Madam President, in office, Mr. Commissioner, I offer my full support to the rapporteur who is defending the position that was ours in the first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to align our legislation on working time with the case law of the Court of Justice. This has now been done.

all childcare time is counted as working time,

one must face reality squarely.

Dear colleagues, we must clearly demonstrate to the Member States' government that the text it wishes to impose on us is unacceptable.

And in the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly ring in the ears of the French government from tomorrow, it seems to me necessary to focus first and foremost on the employees who will be called upon to work ever more, without truly having a choice, and this is true for all those who will be asked tomorrow to work on Sundays in France.
It is, moreover, clearly to open this possibility that the French government has changed its stance on individual opt-out at the Council.

Dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their appeal. If we do not want the negative votes in the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums to be followed by many more, calling into question a European Union that they feel does not address their daily problems, we must act. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. It was a very fine French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices to disagree.
The 27 set aside their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe is taking a first step, and in this regard, this first step is immense.
She now has the means to fulfill her environmental responsibility without sacrificing her economy.
From now on, it can take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland offers a scenario to emerge from its isolation.
Our Irish friends will once again pronounce themselves on the Lisbon Treaty with all the cards in hand, since practically all the other members will have definitively pronounced themselves.
The current crises demonstrate that the Union needs the best institutional tools more than ever to be effective.
The European Council has adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors hardest hit.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his viewpoint.
Let us hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March that seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges facing Europeans provide an opportunity for the Union to reveal itself to them as more united, more responsive, and more concerned with their protection.
We are grateful to the French presidency for having infused this new dynamism.
We, like Nicolas Sarkozy, hope not to see again anytime soon the councils of yesterday that ended at 4 a.m. to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the last six months, Europe has indeed changed in terms of mindset, scope, and credibility.
We must thank the French presidency for this. We are well aware that it is not entirely unrelated. Thank you, Mr. President.

what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we are calling on the Security Council to take a stand. We are asking that the bodies take a stand, that the European Union take a stand. And we, in Parliament, discuss and do not want to take a stand.

I believe that, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of the utmost importance for this Parliament to take a stance and clearly state its position on how to halt the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and clarity to vote on a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group is requesting a revision of the Conference of Presidents' decision and the conclusion of the debate so that we may proceed.
have on the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament's clear and firm position, by a majority, to put an end to the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution. We must be aware that we have a political responsibility regarding what is happening. And this political responsibility cannot merely be a discussion. It must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we condemn.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, now more than ever, the draft directive that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that rapporteur Mr. Cleanse has carried out a long-term, laborious task for years and has negotiated with talent, especially during the Trilogue.

It is also true that the directive makes a number of significant strides towards improving the functioning of the internal market and the collective management of financial assets, and has been welcomed as such by the European investment fund industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, as the outcome was known in advance. For some stakeholders, it was imperative to introduce the European passport for management companies at all costs.
In principle, there is little to object to. The passport is a valid form of defense. However, it is crucial to ensure that the introduction of the passport system for management companies
accompanied by the necessary guarantees, particularly in terms of fund oversight, as it leads to a separation of functions across borders.
Now, I regretfully note that the system in place is not only complex, but it is also subject to divergent interpretations.
They are likely to encounter practical difficulties very quickly, which will harm the European industry, from export funds, in particular exports to third countries.
I have fully acknowledged my minority position, yet I do not feel uncomfortable.
In normal times, I would have been tempted to say that only practice will allow for definitive conclusions in this matter and thus determine.
Who is right between those who trust in the adaptive capabilities of market actors and those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success lies at the end. However, on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial asset management industry, are not reassuring.
Scepticism gives way to my anxiety.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, as we are already witnessing.
Fundamental reevaluations may be necessary in this context of crisis.
In these contexts of deep crisis, making choices that either dilute the responsibilities of the actors or assume perfect cooperation between regulatory authorities can indeed seem incongruous.
I am translating this as I think it should be, this directive is also one from a bygone era before the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is facing a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence. Entire sectors of its architecture must be rethought.

Let us not forget that the primary function of OPCM (Organismes de Placement Collectif en Immobilier) is investor protection through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting for this text as it stands, without truly knowing where we are heading, we are acting as if nothing has happened.
This autism bodes ill, which is why I will abstain, even though I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me, indeed, of little significance in light of the principles I have just explained.

Mr. President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not systematically complying by providing annual reports as requested.
Thus, a comprehensive analysis remains random, as many elements are lacking regarding the resources deployed to conduct inspections.
As a member of animal protection associations and part of the animal defense intergroup, this issue concerns me greatly.
Associations have been fighting desperately for decades, and it was only in 2007 that guidelines were finally established in this area, where Member States have shown a certain degree of laxity.
I would even venture to say a certain lack of goodwill. For, after all, we know that the implementation of control and inspection measures is by no means insurmountable.
We are aware of the slaughterhouse locations, we know the breeding sites, and we are familiar with the livestock transit routes. So, where lies the issue?

I believe it is important in our time, when public opinion is increasingly and rightly sensitive to animal welfare, whether in terms of breeding, slaughter, or transport conditions, that states respect these sentiments.
And since I have the floor, I would like to add regarding transportation that it would be indispensable to consider, independently of travel times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a several-hour journey in the Netherlands in the spring is hardly comparable to the same journey time in midsummer in a country like Greece.
Shouldn't night-time transportation be mandated in these latter cases?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

I am delighted that it was our British colleague, Mr Parish, who tabled this text, which goes to show that the Roman soldiers, 2000 years ago, were right to go to Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then two consequences must be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to locate the food agency in Helsinki. And it is not reasonable for the European Commission not to reverse course on the following points. Firstly, reinstating aid for almond trees. Secondly, halting amendments.

aggressions taking place against olive trees, particularly in Louisiana and across Europe, to halt the aggressions against bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean and the uprooting of European vineyards.
I suggest to our commissioner, our president, Mr. Barroso, that he organize a grand banquet in Portugal featuring ewe's cheese and Saint-Germain wine.
Thank you, Mr. President. Indeed, we have all advocated for the closure of Guantanamo, and we all commend President Obama's decision to shut down this prison of shame.
Today, the question of accepting the detainees from Guantanamo should not be one that we have to consider.
As Europeans, remaining faithful to our values of upholding universal human rights, we must take responsibility, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we have read, and here I am addressing the Council, we have read in the press that some Member States were not very enthusiastic about this reception.
At this point, I would like to make a sincere appeal to the Council and especially to the reluctant Member States to agree to receive these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst would be if the noble effort sparked by the closure of Guantanamo becomes mired in difficulties because we did not step up when Europe was called upon.

important because the European animal feed sector is one of the most significant sectors in agriculture, both in terms of production, as it accounts for half of the agricultural production in the European Union, 120 million tonnes, and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union indeed counts 5 million breeders and 60 million households owning pets.
In the past, the European Union has had to deal with several health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of both farmers and consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of incurring minimal costs for industries while providing significant benefits to consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.
Adopting this report will help mitigate risks by ensuring improved product quality, enhanced control, better traceability, and comprehensive information for breeders, and ultimately, consumers.
Today, with the increase in international trade, it has become imperative to strengthen all preventive measures to ensure that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not recur.

This report succeeds in balancing the right to information while strictly defining the nutritional elements that must mandatorily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, which is crucial for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that manufacturers should indeed be required to immediately notify the use of any new raw material included in animal feed composition to ensure transparency and facilitate inspection by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the addition of a new dangerous substance to the list of prohibited materials seems to me to be absolutely essential.

Similarly, giving the breeder the possibility to consult the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an unfair allegation helps to better secure the system, both to protect the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I would like to offer my full support to this excellent report, as experience has shown that regulation of pet food labeling that prioritizes quality, transparency, traceability, and control is the best way to prevent future health crises in Europe.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Policy, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, are they expected to fund the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today, for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan?
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans fund the reconstruction.
Such is the division of labor among allies.
Now it should be the vandals who pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks focusing on an extended ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable insofar as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right-wing party that is democratically accepted there, risks having its task significantly complicated in these negotiations.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become in the West Bank a sort of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.
The final factor to consider is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has been continuous since 1967, making the establishment of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly challenging.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli court, but do the hawks on both sides accept this divine truce that both parties demand without having the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a reflection on France's reintegration into the integrated military structure of NATO, which will be up for debate with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO at a time when the Cold War has been over since 1990.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia's return to the ranks of free nations.
Should we strengthen the logic of blocs at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries, including in military terms, are occurring?
Moreover, France's adherence to the integrated structure will require it to increase its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has 3,300 troops deployed there.
With what budget will she fund this, given that her defense budget is set to fall below 2% of GDP and over 30 regiments are set to be disbanded?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budget contribution to join NATO while simultaneously reducing our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will thus be a pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
One only needed to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in terms of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, resting in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Thank you, Madam President. I congratulate our three rapporteurs for their remarkable synthesis of the current state of our common foreign and security policy.

Sir, as you know better than anyone, Europe is expected to take its place on the world stage today, a place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanist values.

It is a fact that, despite the regularly expressed desire of more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens, as you have stated, certain progress has indeed been made over the past ten years, I grant you that. However, it must be acknowledged that this Europe still does not exist.
If a recent illustration were needed, his erasure in the resolution of the new drama in the Middle East would serve to demonstrate it.
There has been, and there still is, a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in both aiding the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the territory.
and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had enabled the transformation of this territory into a launch base for rockets of all calibres.
Despite the fine words uttered in Sharm el-Sheikh and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

The transposition into EU law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union in regional fisheries organizations is indeed not a trivial matter, and we insist that it always take place under the democratic scrutiny of our institution.
At the core, I welcome the various proposed measures, which, although restrictive for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at hand. And I emphasize that the most important ones are...

The determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, that you have shown in reaching a satisfactory agreement at the level of the ICCAT.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet undertaken to concretely define territorial cohesion.
The French presidency is being tested there, and I would like to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable as soon as the Lisbon Treaty enters into force, and that its parameters be clarified as soon as possible.

I hope, like the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooy, that territorial cohesion will become the legal basis ensuring the harmonious development of all areas of the Union and enabling us to make the most of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to exclusively target regions suffering from permanent handicaps.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems to me to be relevant for taking into account the outermost regions in order to ensure their sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for incorporating into his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by the outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, indispensable elements of territorial cohesion.
Upon reading the Commission's recent communication entitled "The OUTs: An Asset for Europe", it seems to me that it intends to allocate all resources to the outermost regions.

recommendations concerning the improvement of governance in the area of cohesion, thereby making the regions the first, somewhat anticipated, illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the General States of Overseas France, which will soon commence, will adopt a similar approach and extensively consider the significant territorial impact of European policies in favor of bananas, whose added value is undeniable.

We find it amusing to read the conclusions of the presidency's last Council.
It resembles the victory statement of all defeated armies.
They do so to the point of repeatedly asserting that, once the crisis is over, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or in reaffirming a Lisbon strategy in complete disarray.
Thus, as they lock themselves away in their glass tower, eurocrats, europhiles, and all manner of euro-enthusiasts eventually lose sight of reality.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter a recession, having experienced the lowest interest rates in the world for eight years.
but it is also the one facing the greatest challenges in terms of industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, through the general disarmament of natural defenses taken away from nations, is the least equipped to react.
In reality, the only merit of this crisis will be to awaken the peoples lulled by the ease of financial anticipation and by anti-national propaganda.
Only states will have the legitimate instruments required for any large-scale action, and to do so, they will need to break free from the constraints of the EU and the euro.

For the French, in any case, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty. Thank you, Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that the issue of food distribution to benefit the most deprived is indeed timely, but in essence, I think the Commission's proposal does not address the problem.

The issue of co-financing raises questions for me, and I believe it is rather the question of liberalism, which has guided the evaluations of the CAP in recent years, that should be called into question.
Riots against hunger, the drastic fluctuations in food prices, are constant indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and fragile territories.

I therefore advocate for politics to reclaim its place, to take the lead, both at the European and global levels, and for the strategic field of agriculture and human nutrition, from both a quantitative and qualitative perspective, not to be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Indeed, there is an urgency, and the Sikorsky report addresses this urgency, which I welcome. However, I hope that within the framework of the discussion that is now open on the
Regarding the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the primary objective is indeed to structurally combat the hunger and poverty that we know exist in all Member States and around the world.

Rural territories are available to meet food needs through sufficient and high-quality production. They will, however, require the financial and human resources to fulfill this significant responsibility.
Thank you, Mr. President. During this period of economic recession, it was important for the European Union to continue demonstrating its solidarity with developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and its Member States together contributed 60% of total development aid, making the European Union the world's largest donor.
European development funds enable the fight against poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros has been allocated for the period 2008-2013 under the 10th EDF, which represents almost double the amount planned for the 9th EDF.
The audit, in its report, concludes that the accounts of the 7th, 8th, and 9th European Development Funds (EDF) are, in general, faithful, legal, and regular.
One can only applaud the record levels of contract performance and payments for the implementation of the EDF.
However, I also note that progress needs to be continued in order to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as there is still a significant level of error affecting certain transactions.
Similarly, there is all too often a high risk associated with budget support, and in my view, these risks should be better assessed.
On this matter, I share the view that budgetary support should only be granted if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage the funds in a transparent, responsible, and effective manner.

Among the priorities we need to work on in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the EDF into the Community's general budget, as it would enhance the effectiveness and transparency of development aid.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the Commission staff who did an excellent job on the ground. And I obviously regret the absence of the Council and in particular the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, the Parliament and its rapporteur were compelled to reject a poor compromise. They were right to do so.
Our delegation remained true to the position widely adopted in plenary, which called for the eventual elimination of all derogations to the legal working time.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only one wanting to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided beyond partisan divisions to put an end to this archaic practice known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers blatantly ignored, as did the Commission, for that matter.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any progress in workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your objectives.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all on-call time as working time. Therefore, you have not lost anything in this regard.
The opt-out you desire still exists in practice, so the status quo has prevailed.
More than ever, the MPs elected next June will have to fight for the harmonization of social standards at the highest level.
Sir, Mr. President.

Mr. President, it is certainly not on behalf of the Liberty Commission, but rather most likely on behalf of my group. I would like to take this brief moment to express my extraordinarily positive assessment of Mrs. Paganoff's report.

I believe that in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise set of requirements for elements that should be prominently featured, Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, of which I am aware that the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to all that has been said regarding the importance of judicial training and assessment, by emphasizing two fundamental elements for mutual trust that underpin what could be, tomorrow, mutual recognition.
1. The independence of the judiciary.
At this time, there are a number of countries within the Union where the independence of the judiciary from political power or other powers is not established.
It is a scandal, and this scandal must end.
2. Procedural safeguards.

Until we are certain that in a number of countries, individuals suspected or accused of committing certain types of offenses benefit from procedural guarantees similar to those in place in other nations, it will be challenging to gain widespread acceptance of the principle of mutual recognition.
This is a fundamental element, and I wanted to introduce it into this discussion.
Congratulations, Madame Pagano.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent about the situation in Madagascar. And we will not be alone in condemning this situation.
The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of La Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union represented by the Commission,

The U.S.A., a large number of countries including my own and Norway, to mention European continent countries, have condemned the coup d'tat, because it must be called by its name, which took place in Madagascar.
So we cannot remain silent and we call for a return to constitutional legality.
We merely request a return to the original class, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is the responsibility of Madagascar's assemblies and political leaders to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So what we are asking for with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have taken power in a completely non-tragic manner,

democratic and in a manner, in the form of a coup d'tat however well-disguised, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the future development of this great island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, of course, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, for the attention he continues to pay to all these disasters.
We worked closely together when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report, which he indeed cited, on the establishment of a European civil protection force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006.
And when I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I tell myself that it remains as relevant as ever.
Mrs. Zanlella, of course, it's not just Greece.
All countries are affected. And I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human-made disasters caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the RICAs and how many others, and industrial accidents like Chernobyl.
There are other natural disasters besides fires.
I think of the tsunami,
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one in the early 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messina.

Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we are deploying are not equal to the task of addressing these disasters, which will multiply due to the dual impact of climate change and transportation.
And this is why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I would like to thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all his teams, and the Directorate-General for ensuring the operation of the civil protection mechanism.
I believe we need to go further.
with those member countries that wish to do so. One can envision enhanced cooperation.
If we are not 27 to form this civil protection force, let's start with 12 or 15.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I compile the list of catastrophes, I can say that everyone is affected. The floods that hit Germany in 2002, and even major pandemics, as well as terrorism.
Here, Mr. Commissioner, is why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
And our Parliament, the Environment Committee, the Defense and Security Committee, will support you in these proactive initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Parliament, this summer once again, the Mediterranean forest fell victim to flames in Marseille, in southern Corsica, but also in Italy, Spain, and on a larger scale in Greece.
Over 400,000 hectares of forests and fields have been reduced to ashes, causing significant material damage, irreversible harm to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human life.
appalled by this recurring trend year after year and cognizant of the multiplier effect of climate change on wildfires,
I call for a European awakening to better coordinate efforts and pool resources for firefighting.
I advocate for the realization of a comprehensive Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project to combat forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I welcome the existing initiatives, and in particular the European Forest Fire Information System, a pilot project,
I nonetheless call for a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund to make it an effective tool for responding to crises and to strengthen the European emergency response capacity.
protection and the EuroAid mechanism, designed by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene in the territory of the 27 member states as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of wildfires lies in the sharing of knowledge and best practices in prevention. I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by the forestry firefighters in my own department.
And I can, of course, make this example available to Europe, which can be of use. Thank you.
Good morning, Madam President, good morning, Madam Commissioner. Well, I will be brief.
I believe there are two elements to this debate.
The pressing question is, how can we emerge from this crisis?
And all the measures that go hand in hand, from aiding farmers to intervention measures, are necessary and absolutely essential,
They must be supported, and even considered more significant.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Then secondly, there is a question raised in a structured manner concerning the management of the milk market. And it is here that there is a divergence between us, Madam Commissioner.
You propose to move towards contractualization.
I am telling you in advance, contracting between industry and agriculture in the long term, with industries being competitive with each other, will lead to a Europe-wide competition.
We need public regulation to control a market.
There is no other alternative.
This is where the debate must engage after this crisis.
And I believe that in this debate, we must respect all opinions and options. And I fear that we moved too quickly during the health check to resolve an issue like quotas.

And up until now, I have been telling all those who have intervened that their actions have made it possible to maintain dairy production in Europe, to support a highly developed dairy industry, and at the same time, to ensure a price for consumers that has been entirely manageable. Mr. President, a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I truly feel that we can say that we are more European today than before.
I truly, fully, and serenely rejoice in it.
Unfortunately, we are still essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, as well as the goodwill of the Czech president.
A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold in their hands the future of this crucial treaty for the Union, for our institutions, and for the 500 million Europeans we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few individuals whose sole purpose is to undermine the broader European interest.

While it is legitimate for some to wish not to proceed further with European integration, and while it is legitimate to express these reservations, it is equally legitimate to allow those who wish to do so to progress.
In general, the processes for ratifying European treaties all too often resemble a saga or a Pyrrhic victory.
Are we doomed to continually have to push hard to ensure the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We will need to draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this negotiation commitment with a view to organizing a second ratification.
referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to make a people vote again after they have expressed themselves sovereignly, and as if it were normal for consent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.

Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion once one has chosen for one's country to accede to the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty in advance of the European elections in June 2009.
What do you think the citizen today thinks of the Treaty of Lisbon and beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Thank you, Mr. President. My intervention concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world's workers earn less than $2 per day.
12.3 million people are still subjected to slavery, and over 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor increases day by day, and the International Labour Organization records 160,000 deaths annually due to a lack of prevention measures.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in undignified conditions.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide, or victims of cancers or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to step away from the religion of working more, from the pursuit of profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union's priorities in the coming ten years.
President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To take up the gauntlet, Copenhagen must facilitate a comprehensive agreement, a single accord, as our Environment Committee chair, Jola Nenoui, emphasized earlier. An alliance of all nations, both industrialized and emerging, is necessary.

Today, through our debate and also the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we once again call on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is imperative that we speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
And yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in global average temperature to a level that does not exceed 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, in Copenhagen we must sign an agreement to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1997 levels.
But this will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also for developing countries to contribute to the achievement of the goals.

Industrialized countries must therefore provide sufficient, lasting, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus enable developing countries to move towards low-carbon models.
Therefore, allow me to explore two avenues that seem essential for our future.
Firstly, the establishment at a global level of climate change mitigation financing based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Subsequently, it seems necessary to me to implement a border tax adjustment for Europe that will pre-import products manufactured without any regard for environmental protection.

a contractualization and a transfer to the countries of the Global South of the carbon tax thus collected at the borders of Europe, which would serve to finance investments in equipment necessary for the fight against global warming

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to speak in the same vein as my intervention yesterday on the preparation for the Copenhagen summit, especially following the Ecofin meeting yesterday, which was not a success.
I have addressed you regarding the responsibility we have, as industrialized nations, to ensure that developing countries can join us in our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities. Otherwise, it would mean that we all start from the same point and ultimately end up achieving nothing.
So to convince our development partners to join us, we will obviously need to address the issue of the aid that should be granted to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the upcoming European Council, the 27 members must absolutely reach an agreement on how the European Union envisions aiding developing countries within the crucial context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I was saying, Finance Minister Coffin's advisor failed to find a common position on this issue.
Yet, we know that this question is absolutely central.

The European Commission had already made proposals. I absolutely want us to take the lead in order to bring our partners towards the global solidarity necessary to overcome this problem of climate change.
The Swedish presidency's efforts to reach an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the very strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe it is not realistic at this stage to admit that the Copenhagen summit was stillborn or that it will not lead to a conclusive agreement for all parties to ratify.
Let us not yield too quickly to pessimism.
I argue that at this stage, we should not scale back our ambitions, either in terms of goals or deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline for the COP16 in December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
We need to clarify our commitment in financial terms and in terms of aid to developing countries, particularly in terms of technology transfer.
At this point, a full and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent but exemplary momentum given, to speak, by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway in particular, which have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While we can understand the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate issue, we must still achieve quantified, binding, and ambitious short-, medium-, and long-term commitments from other major polluters such as the United States and China.
In the absence of action, we are heading towards a climate, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and have stated the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but while we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept one at any cost.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I strongly wish for the European Union to be able to say no and refuse to sign a watered-down deal.
The European populations we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that will enable us to effectively combat all the climate disruptions we observe around us every day.
They will not be satisfied with mere announcements, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives that can be easily dismissed once the media spotlight has moved on.

In Copenhagen, states must commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, and the only continent to pledge specific, binding, and ambitious future targets, cannot bear the burden of the effort alone.

This is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to bear their share of the burden, we must draw all the consequences by introducing at our borders a tax that protects our industry from the competition of those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans demand a little more each day from our industries.
As evidence, I point to the Climate Package that was signed under the French presidency.

As evidence, I point to national initiatives such as the carbon tax, which was praised earlier by Mr. Parniaud, and I welcome this. These initiatives encourage the establishment of ecological taxation.

A sector like transportation, which is among the major emitters of CO2, even though certain modes of transport such as aviation emit less greenhouse gas, is contributing increasingly to the fight against climate change.
Now, this is a sector that has been hit very hard by the backlash of the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are included in the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries is also demanded of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, world public opinion will have its eyes firmly fixed on its leadership.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen Summit is an historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must reach decisions that are even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We, too, must call on our leaders to create an international organization, akin to the WTO, tasked with regulating climate change and environmental issues, to establish a form of fundamentalism.
in addition to, of course, public development aid, to create a maritime and air carbon tax, as should also be done for financial transactions.
We clearly see the pressing necessity for global regulation of the environment, much like that of financial markets and the Internet.
We have the opportunity to open this chapter in history through the lens of the environment.
Let us do so, in keeping with our highest human aspirations, otherwise we will appear as mere bystanders, with no influence on the reality of things. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Council President, Mr. Commission President, and dear colleagues. With less than two weeks until the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing about the success of climate change negotiations.
Some, in fact, are already saying that it will be a failure.
major world powers are still reluctant to show the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of us.

By adopting the resolution proposal tomorrow on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen conference, we European parliamentarians must demonstrate that our resolve is first and foremost unwavering and that the conference must result in an agreement that is indeed precise, but above all, binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once reached, must not be subject to challenge or dispute.

We cannot indefinitely postpone decision-making until tomorrow, or it will be too late. Hence the necessity to create a world environmental organization, which today appears not only necessary but also urgent, as it will be called upon, under the auspices of the United Nations, to monitor the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must, from Copenhagen onwards, expect significant pressure from the world, as well as greater clarity and responsibility.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British Socialist government and the French government to repatriate Afghans in an illegal situation to their territory.
Indeed, contrary to what some people have stated, these individuals had their applications for political asylum rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.

The migratory pressure is a challenge that we must address collectively. This is the essence of the pact on migration and asylum, voted on a few months ago, adopted a few months ago under the French presidency.
We must now go further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights funded by Frontex.

The decision by the 27 to request a study on this subject from the Commission is a first step. Commissioner, I hope the Commission will support this proposal, as combating illegal immigration is a public expectation and particularly of the immigrant populations in regular status. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to revisit a recent event, the Swiss vote on minarets.

I would like to revisit this event as I also see it as a pretext to discuss secularism, and one cannot speak enough about secularism in this chamber.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism underpins the organization of our society. And I would like to state some simple things here.
Firstly, the principle contrary to secularism is not religiosity, nor is it spirituality.
The principle contrary to secularism is religious communalism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws. Communalism that confines individuals within subsocietal groups.
Our union, by its history, is multicultural and multi-ethnic.
It will be increasingly so, and only secularism can enable individuals...
The Csar program, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

Is the Commission going to follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, which stated that a high-level, qualified individual should oversee the political follow-up of this program?

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues. The importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in doubt.

These short-, medium-, or long-term impacts are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper make the front page and certainly strengthen the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen Summit presented itself to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to bear witness, take action, and rectify the effects of the process that is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this platform, not only because of the bold legislation we have in place to limit the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe stands as a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a bitter taste, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has reached an agreement on the issue of limiting temperature rise to 2C, and this includes even a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in line with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated great ambition regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
I think of Japan and Norway.
Moreover, it is also important to highlight this very positive point, which was the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism to reduce emissions from deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text has been achieved on the implementation of the Direct Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO2 storage.
Far from a binding agreement, but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen must lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen conference, like many of my colleagues, with a strong desire to participate, to help, and to witness an negotiating Europe, a leading Europe, in action.
My disappointment was great as Europe clearly did not receive the place it deserved in the negotiations, all the more so when it comes to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on this issue.
The meeting of our environment ministers in Seville was inconclusive. Our leaders have shown uncertainty and hesitation, and we remain divided on our goals.
I hope that Ms. Edegarde, drawing on her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Committee, will be able to bring the European Union's ambitions up to date.

Thank you. I call on Mr. Buddhist. Dear colleagues, to avoid caricatures, we have heard a few this morning, I would like to recall some objective facts about Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average per capita income, and now the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

Over 90% of Tunisians benefit from social security coverage, and more than a quarter of Tunisia's budget is dedicated to education, such that the country is among the first to have achieved the millennium goals in primary education.
Finally, as Mr. Michel reminded us earlier, women's rights are recognized and guaranteed.
At university, there are more female students than male students. Forty percent of professors are women. A quarter of members of parliament, local elected officials, or journalists are women.
Many countries could envy such results.

What is the Commission's vision on this subject?
Moreover, my concern, like many of my colleagues, revolves around equity.
How can we ensure that vessels flying the flags of countries such as Tunisia, Libya, or others will enforce the ban on international trade with a rigor comparable to our own?
What will the new control measures and sanctions be?

The sustainability policy of our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary to implement these measures.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has stated, this proposal for a directive indeed follows a vote by the Parliament, a point you also emphasized, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal because it risks backfiring on those we intend to support.
In seeking to reduce the burdens on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust indispensable to their management and the dynamism of their activities.
Firstly, I believe it is necessary to be clear about the thresholds and what is meant by micro-entities.
These are SMEs with more than 10 employees and a turnover of over 1 million euros.
Regardless of the member state, this represents a very large majority of businesses.
Undoubtedly, they may be local and have little presence in the community market, but it remains that the requirement to present accounting rules will not be abolished for them and that these...
accounting rules, they will have to grapple with them whenever they wish to deal with a banking institution, partners, or occasionally negotiate with tax, economic, and social institutions.
At that time, accounting rules will be imposed on them, and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they will not necessarily control.
I do not see any progress in imposing the accounting obligation outside of any common framework for the European Union.
This is not merely a competition issue. It is quite simply a matter of economic integration and Community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses in the European Union.
In other words, clearly, simplifying accounting requirements for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives are moving in this direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today or the international IFR framework.
whether it is the revision of the Fourth and Seventh Accounting Directives, for which the European Commission should soon be making proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it seems they will be extended, but I do not believe that this deadline extension is sufficient reason for...
to rush and do a half-hearted job. For these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same structure. And it seems to me, Commissioner, that it would be better,

and clearer for businesses, to provide them with a unique and comprehensive solution that will enable them to balance the goal of simplifying obligations, which is desired by all, with the practical realities of small businesses that need it.
The current issue is that the European Commission is delaying the proposal to revise these directives, which is hindering our discussions.

I therefore call on the European Commission to expedite the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact assessment.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues,

As my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and others have pointed out, on February 27th and 28th, the violent storm Cynthia struck several French regions, causing 53 fatalities and extensive material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity. It caused devastating floods along the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadec, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and Pays de la Loire.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not just through words and a resolution, but above all through financial assistance that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore call on, and my colleague Christophe Bchus joins me in this request, the European Commission to unlock the EU Solidarity Fund swiftly to assist the affected regions in dealing with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are increasing and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jrg Leichtfried, on his text and his cooperative spirit in this matter. I particularly support his proposals regarding the financing of air safety, as we are discussing air safety here, not air security.
For many years, our Commission has been fighting to have the principle accepted that stricter safety measures should be borne by the Member States. I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not only concern travelers, but all citizens. And it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore unjustified for air passengers alone to bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And all the more so given that in transport modes such as rail and maritime, states fund security measures either partially or fully, depending on the case.
And I therefore believe that we need to stand firm against the Council and defend Amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Transport Committee to the very end.
So I had another point to briefly address

While I support the progress on non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, identical European system for safety fees.
While enforcing adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of fee collection.

And so, in countries like Spain, Italy, or France, royalties are voted on by Parliament. In this case, it is the authority responsible for challenging laws that must serve as the independent supervisory authority.
This is the purpose of Amendment 40, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The report I am presenting to Parliament aims to explain that in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature, and volcanoes in particular, reminded us this week that they can have a significant impact on human activities and the climate.
But this nonetheless requires that men and Europe in particular take responsibility to combat what is known as climate change.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil energy, and above all, adopt a different approach.
side has actively contributed to carbon sequestration as part of a global effort to reduce carbon emissions and increase the amount of carbon captured and stored.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we need to move away from a compartmentalized approach, where every time we face a problem, we create a new directive.
on soils, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and trying to tackle the agricultural issue with the ambition to address it comprehensively, systematically.
And in this approach, we need to identify ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is close to my heart, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

And I believe that this path I am opening in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in the European Parliament in Brussels, this path must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability and ensure a...

ecological transition in this agriculture, which would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, to ensure that it can be economically efficient, ecologically sound, and I believe also, from that point onwards, socially beneficial.

This report addresses a specific issue: the fight against climate change and agriculture. However, it aims, I hope, to open up other perspectives to inform, in particular, the debate that will take place on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
And I address the Commission, I will address, and I have often done so, the agricultural committees, I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity,
I believe we need to take a turn.
It is essential that this 2013 CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) be ambitious.
