It is essential that it be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because agricultural Europe must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
In any case, this is what I propose in this report, and I hope that the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow me on this.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to emphasize first and foremost that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration. Under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and full reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights is, at the very least, indecent.

So I believe it was Mr. Hnin who just spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with the train. And I will take this opportunity to express how much I regret the paralysis of air transport...
has been exacerbated in certain countries like France by the disruption of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the provision of state aid to airlines affected by the ongoing disruptions.
This is a decision driven by common sense in a context already marred by crisis, but such aid must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I hope that the exemplary nature demonstrated by airlines in the compensation awarded to their customers affected by flight cancellations will be included as one of the criteria for the ROC 3 rating.
Indeed, it is unacceptable for certain companies to abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers under Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation, and if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not also bear the financial cost.
Moreover, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
And this, too, is not normal.

Companies like travel agencies have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, such as the situation we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for the flights that have been canceled.
Thank you, Mr. President. Chaos, mayhem, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disasterthe press is not short of words to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been mentioned, particularly regarding the immense, one might say abyssal, financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

And while I welcome the possibility of considering the provision of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been widely approved since 11 September 2001, I remain perplexed by the European management of these events.

Given that 750,000 European passengers have been stranded, many of whom remain blocked across the globe. Given that economic losses are exponential with each passing day. How can it be explained that it took not just...

not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European Transport Ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the establishment of differentiated traffic zones.
Two, no one disputes the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority. But today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in certain areas,
With the weather remaining unchanged and the volcano still active, one is entitled to wonder what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.

Three. An adaptive action plan has been developed. The situation can change hourly due to weather conditions and volcanic activity. Who will continue to conduct ongoing safety assessments of the corridors?
Must these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this persists, worsens, or recurswhich is likelythe established management model should provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data, as well as improved

coordination of other transport means in exceptional circumstances, but also take into consideration the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have the right to information and support.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Thank you, Madam President. In turn, following other speakers, I would like to express my gratitude to our colleague Mends Divigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
Debates within the Convention Affairs Committee lasted a long time. They were commensurate with the stakes and with the intensity and interest that are, of course, brought to bear by
European Parliamentarians in the major issue that rightfully concerns them first and foremost, the composition of our assembly and the procedures for appointing the members of our assembly.
Once again, the rapporteur has successfully gathered sometimes differing opinions and contributions, and has synthesized, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the various views and opinions.
I wanted to thank him for it.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one regarding transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
This, I believe, is what citizens, globally and on other topics as well, expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dali, Mr. Commissioner, it is with great conviction that this draft report, as presented a moment ago by Mr. Pterl, reiterates the main principles...
Director of Communication of the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to endorse the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to more effectively combat cancer, whether it be the importance of prevention, early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities among Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed within the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to acknowledge the work done by Mr. Pterl, rapporteur, in drafting this report, and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As a shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat Group, I wished to emphasize, among other things, the following issues. Firstly, the increase in annual cancer deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access to information.

It seems the French text you need translated is missing from your message. Please provide the specific French text you'd like me to translate, and I will deliver the English translation according to your instructions.

For instance, if your French text is:

"La comprhension interculturelle est essentielle dans un monde globalis."

My translation would be:

"Intercultural understanding is essential in a globalized world."

containing chemical substances that are carcinogenic and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union. And finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancers.
These are the questions we wished to raise while supporting this draft report.
Yes, thank you, Madam President. The oil rig leak in the Gulf of Mexico is an actual ecological and economic catastrophe.
It would appear that irregularities have been identified in the granting by the United States Department of the Interior of forest permits.
This would be an unforgivable negligence with incalculable consequences, which do not only concern the United States of America.

When we consider that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by nations worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same lack of caution, it would pose a serious and genuine problem for the entire world.
elected representatives from the European Union's outermost regions and the OCTs composed entirely or almost entirely of islands, nearly 130 of them.
In total, spread across the three continents, I must express here my profound concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, as a role model, rigorously re-examines its security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
In addition, accidental or operational offshore oil spills, not necessarily originating from Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tonnes each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives to ensure that offshore platforms now fall under the purview of an undisputed international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international body?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancn, the European Union would do well to initiate genuine global governance for the exploration, protection, and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
Building on the Barcelona process, the Union for the Mediterranean is an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the Eastern and Southern Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report by Vincent Pion underscores, we cannot overlook either the potential of this region or the perils it carries.
Yet, with the clarity to acknowledge it, since the bombing of Gaza and with the continuing colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn in the coming hours or days that he is about to begin his day's work.
We must not give up for all that. But the European Union must take greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot allow the United States to have a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region are crucial to our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best tool at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important matter regarding consumer protection.
A recent survey shows that the food security situation has deteriorated in the eyes of Europeans over the past ten years. One in three consumers remains skeptical about the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color-coding, we are in favor of this system provided it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as percentages.
And then, I am opposed to a mandatory nutritional labeling requirement for wines and spirits.
We would like to see the development of a specific regulation for wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
This is what I wished to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian vessels by Israeli commandos clearly demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we attribute to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters, and thus concerns the international community, particularly the European countries bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more strongly and become more actively involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making significant financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is largely absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of a Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill that we demonstrate is not sufficient.
We must also express political will and take the necessary steps to make our voices heard.
The brutal assault on the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli military has elicited outrage and condemnation.
emotion before the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation because this boarding in international zones constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its own people, for ultimately, we see that with the strengthening of extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region is moving further out of reach.
Yes, now more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.

I would like to point out, however, that the intense media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I hope that the government of Israel agrees to a substantial international participation in this investigation to finally restore the paths of justice in the region. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the partnership for modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were to achieve nothing else, would at least have the merit of underscoring the extent to which Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the demands of the Union are always prioritized, the interests or positions of its partner are systematically undervalued or dismissed, whether in the realm of energy or in how it may perceive the Eastern Partnership and the Atlanticist aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness demonstrated by most member states and the European Union in their speeches, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, appears to be reserved solely for Russia.

The rhetoric is more cautious, the diplomacy more nuanced, as if it were about China, for example, these systematic violations of the rule of law, even regarding the Laogai, this global factory in terms of minimal European social standards, while our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of the adage "Ad angusta per augusta," or "To the heights, by the narrow paths," for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that for so many decades bled and confined this country.
The current Russian Confederation has managed to lift the head of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that remain to be overcome.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen of the Europeanist camp, especially when the European super-state itself fails to achieve any of its noble objectives, despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive domination of the states of Western, Central, and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this assembly showed more leniency towards the Soviet Union than it did towards Russia.

It is often the same individuals who, yesterday, advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common house, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty regarding the European Union-Russia partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, in case you are not already aware, of new historical facts that will come to light due to the gradual translation of the Soviet secret archives that a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov managed to obtain. Archives that have already revealed and will continue to reveal much information.

unpleasant surprise to the classic of monolithic thinking regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was indeed, Mr. Gorbachev, and the deceit of today's Eurocentric powers who then enthusiastically sought to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and shared risks than are certain states that you are nonetheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Mr. President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
In the face of the crisis, an obviousness, I would say an inescapable necessity: the need to innovate, to be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant leap, leading us towards genuine economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, mere coordination of economic policies will remain inadequate.
Might we achieve a genuine budgetary federation, not forced upon us by circumstances, but because we ourselves have decided it?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which nonetheless please me.
Strengthening the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a positive step, but there can be no true budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened, but not yet specified. This is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with regard to the decided orientations, such as the famous competitiveness assessment dashboard, for that is indeed what it is about: regaining competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
It further advocates the establishment of a bank tax, the acceptance of a financial transactions tax, and the acceleration of financial regulations reform.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed, just a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or indeed hypothetical.
You are correct, it is true, it is a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policy.
However, that being said, it is now mandatory for states to implement these guidelines very concretely in October.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious hope, something we will all bitterly regret, and in particular a majority of citizens, who will have to endure it in their daily lives. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on the Gallo report, and clearly, Parliament, all the groups, still need to discuss it further because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
Therefore, this is why we were requesting to postpone the debate and vote on the Gallo report, that is, until September, September 2nd, when the Conference of Presidents will need to be consulted.
So it's a very simple thing.
Given that the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to mature and discuss it in September.

Thank you, Madam President. I must admit that I struggle to follow my colleagues who are so keen to flex their muscles and claim an exclusive hold on our legitimacy in comparison to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a well-argued position,
We defend what resembles a European general interest against rigid states; the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament has played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I am the shadow rapporteur for my group, I advocated, like the rapporteur Ms Goulard, for an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms that ensure a certain level of efficiency, and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
Because the European Central Bank is indeed the only community institution within this framework, and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I shall refrain from mentioning the names of all the institutions and those great figures who suddenly vanished during the storm.
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow's macro-prudential supervision supported by a strong community institution, while micro-prudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
We have neglected this so much, the European Systemic Risk Board must start working as soon as possible.
The future will reveal whether adjustments are necessary, but it is crucial to start from a sound foundation, as systemic risks impact the entire European and global banking sector. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The final agreement reached on the overhaul of the industrial emissions directives is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.

This final package incorporates the key points of the position that I advocated with several of my colleagues within the Environment Committee, aiming to make this text a bold yet realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and now, limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS Directive and permanently removes the somewhat irrelevant idea of creating a SO2 and NOX quota market from the text of the new directive.
A few caveats to bear in mind, however, and more specifically the provisions relating to the ground.
The SOL directive still being pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by those Member States with their own specific legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogues.

Enormous efforts have been made from all sides to avoid sending this text to conciliation, a text which, I must remind you, is of crucial importance for both industry and European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings new information revealing the full scale of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the offshore platform rupture.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind are happening elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and has been for a long time, in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding platform management, not just European rules, but also international regulations.
as far as the European Union is concerned. I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with tools to combat this disaster, and I think it is evident.
as all this argues, as Mrs Damanaki said, for a firm and resolute choice in favour of clean and renewable energies.
and the European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is set to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market will benefit European livestock farmers in disadvantaged areas without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe purchases 38 million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies, Cargill, ADM, and Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It was one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for animal feed.
Sustainable agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be undone by this bilateral agreement project.
Once again, the European Commission is sacrificing its agriculture and farmers to obtain random concessions for service sector companies.
These concessions will not benefit the peasant families of Mercosur, but rather the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To convince oneself of this, one need only read the report by the Tyson group. An American company, it is a major player in the international meat market,
who announces having invested in Brazil to, I quote, and this is from their report, "use this country as an export platform for Europe."
Other companies, like Doux, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
many poultry farmers, especially in Brittany, had borne the brunt of this operation.
Europe, without intending to continue its policy of offshoring by intensifying its attacks
against the peasants. We must stop
Yes, Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the potential impact on European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, there is cause for concern, and as a representative of an ultra-peripheral region, I have experience with the banana agreements. Therefore, it is feared that an agreement with Mercosur could impose a difficult cost on many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a concern that this agreement may further tilt the agriculture of the Mercosur countries towards a productivist model, to the detriment of small-scale farms that exist in these nations.

A balance must therefore be struck so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers rooted essentially in the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Rowe.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would just like to point out that we may not have managed our agenda effectively today.
If we allow free trade agreements to be implemented in Europe, allowing products that do not meet our social or environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be pointless.
Quite clearly, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints,
to our farmers on the grounds that consumers must be protected, while at the same time allowing products to enter our continent freely without adhering to these standards.
The question that lies at the heart of the negotiation with Mercosur is indeed this one.

And the way things have been initiated, regardless of what we are told about the Parliament being fully informed and the process being conducted with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to view the negotiation positively, especially as the parallel negotiation at the WTO continues.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection, and the defense of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Thank you, Madam President. I would also like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, Jos Bov, and welcome the Commissioner. I also appreciate the contribution of Mr. Dess, who spoke before me, regarding the objectives of this report.
I believe it is crucial for us to bear in mind that in our debate, we are addressing an issue related to price volatility in agriculture, particularly the fact that when prices rise,
They are very quickly reflected at the distribution level. And when prices fall at the production level, there is no impact on consumers.
So there is indeed an organizational problem within the sector, there is indeed an issue with the distribution of what is referred to as value added within the sector.

And I believe that Jos Bov's report provides, on several points, perspectives that should be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission, in an attempt to break out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the power dynamics within it.
What proposals do we have for bringing producers together, organizing them, and giving them more weight within the sector to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Commissioner for Interprofessional Relations, but it is also a question that arises from the contractual basis that will be established.
And I argue, as is noted in the report, that this contractual basis is a European framework.
We cannot leave it to each country to solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, an inseparable lead for me.
Secondly, of course, the issue of price transparency.
In this regard, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary to enable us to inform consumers about price developments.
So, here is my support for the proposals put forward, and I hope, as Mr. Desse said, that there will be a majority to follow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, today I would like to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to recognize and valorize its regional diversity.
At a time when negotiations are underway for the new framework programmes 2014-2020, I believe it is important to emphasize the adjustments that specific regions should benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the forefront of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, insular, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We need to implement the tools that can synergistically coexist all areas of community action in order to enhance their added value.
Furthermore, as a representative of the outermost regions, I eagerly await the new Union strategy for the OUTR, which the Commission services have promised us for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, firstly, I align myself with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit cavalier on the Council's part, I also want to say.
So as the upcoming summit of October 6 approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely attempt to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at this very time, we were already busy in this very hemicycle urging Europe to do everything in its power to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not meet our expectations and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, if not even more acute.

In order to constrain or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, showing, for instance, that we provide the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the Global South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy's speech at the UN, is becoming a necessary imperative.
For instance, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat in the end. And a way to protect our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalue family leave is not in question. Increasing the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing its economic impact to the qualitative benefit, which is difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold. 1. The economic context is indeed a factor, but it is not sufficient to continue neglecting millions of families for decades. 2. The legal gaps in the report, as the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's take the adoption leave mentioned in the text, on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the willingness to grant rights equivalent to those of biological mothers.
In fact, I am the small additional package mentioned by Mrs. Morin, added to the Estrella report.

If the goal is indeed to enhance the health and rights of women, all women in the labor market, adopting mothers, having become mothers just like the others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
They are mothers like any others, fully entitled to adopt a child, whether under or over 12 months of age. There is no discrimination, please note, as stated in the text.
As for adoption, I regret that the text was not more thoroughly explored.
It was not even informed by the Rambol impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs Estrella's report, because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better fulfill their parental responsibilities in a society that

increasingly resigned when it comes to the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, and Mr. President of the Council. I would like to intervene and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed a 2011 budget within the constraints we know, namely those of a deep crisis that Europe is going through, with national public deficits, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, where these national deficits must provide a new direction and a fresh impetus at the European level.
That is the question.
And I ask you, Commissioner, above all to try to think, when we discuss a budget revision, when we are about to start talking about the budget perspectives for the period after 2013, not to...
remaining fully immersed in the context of the crisis. Unless I am to say, and to tell all the citizens of Europe, that the European continent will undeniably remain in crisis for a prolonged period.
Our entire problem is indeed managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt. But it is also about preparing for the post-crisis period.
And this is where the budget question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, and Joseph Dehde immediately pointed this out, if the European budget, precisely because it is European, can provide us with the means to regain what is lacking in our current situation: growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the crux of the matter. And it is in this context that we should discuss the budget, rather than constantly incorporating the issue of the crisis and the question of deficits, as we so often do. In this regard, the Council is excellent.

I have observed that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a treaty reform, without even discussing with Mr. Van Rompuy at all, to penalize all states that would not adhere to fiscal discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand at the Council level today, as Parliament is only asking one thing, especially of the Commission, which is to try to drive the European project forward. And this is happening through the budget.
So you have noted a number of points on which we are in complete agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Obviously, we need to collectively find a way to have a much more flexible budget. This is because the needs are there, and the reactivity of Europe is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this. All in agreement. It is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need to have a timetable. We need to set joint objectives together, Commissioner. It cannot remain just words, just commitments, just

texts that are, moreover, very interesting and that I agree with almost 100%. But now, we need to get down to the specifics. And in particular on a crucial question that we keep circling around, namely own-resources.

How can we ensure clean resources for Europe's citizens tomorrow? Not just for Europe, but for all European citizens. And to find together again the path to growth and an even stronger path for Europe's future.
The floor is yours, Commissioner.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation of the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers regarding European economic governance, the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the Stability and Growth Pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges facing our nations, and indeed the members of the G20, which must be addressed, in my view, at the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that on these two issues, which are genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must take action...

manage to organize themselves, to agree on common positions, to give themselves the means to speak with one voice at the upcoming G20 summits, in Seoul, but also at those to follow, and more broadly on the world stage. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposal it contains.
So, this also demonstrates that the European Parliament is fully engaged in a debate that is crucial for Europe's future, and we can only commend this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis served as a revealer of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
So I note on this point Mr. Feillot's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want to achieve a sustainable improvement in the budget situation of the states, which is not always popular,
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

I believe that the report clearly highlights the issues surrounding the marine environment in terms of fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, research combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In light of such a finding. It is therefore incumbent upon the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading naval power that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it must be acknowledged that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that one can claim to occupy a position of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, as they are present in all oceans, a change could have been made.
It was wise to give them a leading role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not retained in the report, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam Commissioner, Sir, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Moreover, 75 American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He deems that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
As the European Parliament is about to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, as you know, it still raises significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I believe it would be useful to have a very clear response from our American interlocutors. On two points, can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is Acta, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already absent of China, India, and Brazil, which is not implemented by the United States, would significantly lose its credibility.
I thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Throughout this challenging birth of the alternative investment fund managers directive, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle may sound like an obvious truth, but that truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature.
I would like to thank the negotiators, and in particular our rapporteur, Mr Gauzs, who, after this particularly painful birth for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize above all that the issue of the treatment of third countries should be viewed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in large part to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can then speak of a more or less "level playing field".

It remains that during the transitional period, non-European Union entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while European Union funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets located outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It will then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world as they will be less flexible and more costly.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was to some extent inevitable.

As for depositaries, let us also be aware that we will make the task more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities that will fall upon them. Their increased involvement should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to express my opposition, but to point out that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, though necessary, will also present challenges that we must be aware of.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients require appropriate information to be fully engaged in their care journey. They need to know where to seek care, decide on the best treatment in consultation with healthcare professionals, and strictly adhere to the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we consider to be nonsensical in terms of addressing the real needs of patients.
This operation holds no interest for either citizens or Member States.
This meant, on the contrary, additional bureaucracy, increased costs, and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a proposal to reject these texts, thereby requesting that the Commission revise its approach.
This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schilter from the Greens group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I welcome, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled some sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled a greater emphasis on patients' right to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments secured, we have resolved to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has progressed in a favorable direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has succeeded in counterbalancing the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to oppose the instrumentalization of healthcare professionals to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial-scale information campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot freely flow from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience shows that we need to be extremely vigilant. Indeed, and to conclude, the events surrounding the drug Mediator demonstrate the extent to which we must remain vigilant and ensure that this balance point, which we sought to achieve with this draft report, is maintained.
Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Minister. Unity and realism, I hope, will be reflected in tomorrow's vote on our resolution for this 16th Conference of the Parties on Climate Change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to advance the pragmatic objectives that we must collectively achieve, while also upholding the non-negotiable conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness from our fellow citizens and industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is far too little protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for all that, sell short our present and future knowledge, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standards, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tactic.
Finally, and this is more contentious, as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current clean development mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the true negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.

But the willingness of many European parliamentarians, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference should be encouraged, not neglected, as we have felt in recent days.
If Europe aims to be strong within international dialogues, the same must be true for all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union often presents Economic Partnership Agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Is she then despairing that these agreements are not signed as soon as possible?
But the question that intrigues us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so beneficial to them.
Clearly, there are differing opinions on the quality of these agreements. And as long as these discrepancies persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to deepen the dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
These actors wish to discuss development strategy, while Europe often responds solely with market opening.
It is this listening that the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly imposes upon itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow suit if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets." The goal is their complete and utter departure from this region. A region that saw the birth of Christianity and where their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation in light of the situation.
Any and all forms of discrimination are intolerable.
Democracy will only triumph in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Colleagues, we are all confronted with the serious crisis currently unfolding in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country's Constitutional Council to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the Independent Electoral Commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Paritary Parliamentary Assembly, the EU-ACP Union, the CoAs, and soon, undoubtedly, the European Parliament, are all calling for the respect of the official proclamation.

election results and the inauguration of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. I would like to remind you that this Commission is a body validated by the United Nations.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for a halt to any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, something that must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Thank you, Madam President. In turn, I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and have significantly enhanced the value of the European Parliament's contribution to the texts initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen's initiative that we, in the EPP, are about to vote on with enthusiasm is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly transform the European political landscape. Provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I emphasize, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.

It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is, men and women who are citizens of Europe, debating together, taking positions together, and rallying around truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to swiftly adopt the implementing measures where necessary. Let us not disappoint our fellow citizens; the strengthening of European democracy is at stake. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. In turn, like several of our colleagues, I wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly the Christians of the East.
We do not need to recall the horrible acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to reiterate this point, as well as defend Christians in the East and around the world, advocate for religious freedom, and promote the diversity of
It is advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, values that are at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, universal values, as we are all convinced here.
It is truly time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and of course solemn condemnations, it is truly time to move from words to action.
And so I urgently call upon the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the foreign ministers,
implement precise measures and establish a clear, concrete plan of action to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
And allowing a lawless zone to establish itself at Europe's gates is a danger we must firmly and promptly combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I deplore the loss of life and hostage-takings, and I am concerned for the European citizens on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms, or human traffickers are bypassing Morocco by transiting through Mauritania to the Canary Islands en route to the European Union.
It is, it seems to me, the responsibility of the European Union to act to assist these states in bringing an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake not only on our territory but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to assist in the return to security in the Sahel.
I join in the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been extended to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
He represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been criticized for its lack of response, must firmly stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian people to help them successfully open their countries to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in initiating a peaceful transition, preparing the organization of upcoming elections to achieve freedom and enable the Tunisian people to attain the prosperity of development and social peace, an economy that will allow youth to find employment.

In conclusion, I would say that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded us on numerous occasions,

At a time when Europe is questioning itself about a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthen European standards to improve the operation of collection chains. Address issues of leakage or illegal export of said materials. Furthermore, increase our collection targets, but these must also be incorporated into this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial. If we want to implement effective legislation,
And to achieve this, my dear Karl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
Electric and electronic equipment producers must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot absolve citizens of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, of European environmental policy.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to echo the point just made by Ms. McGuinness regarding the essential link between the food issue and the agricultural question.
The issue that concerns us is the rise in food prices, and the consequences this may have for numerous populations around the world, including in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The tendency towards increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw material prices is, for me, a long-term trend that will persist for three key reasons. The first is the demographic evolution of the world and the resulting price increases.

of the global population. Secondly, the fact that with climate warming, we have entered a phase of climate variability that poses problems, whether it be drought or flooding. And the third point, because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
Thus, the tension in agricultural markets and agricultural raw materials is a significant and persistent trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility. And price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is on this very issue that we must also focus if we are to address both the agricultural question and the food question.

And to achieve this, what the commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, there needs to be transparency about stocks. But there also needs to be a public policy on stocks, both in Europe and globally, particularly at the level of the UN.

And secondly, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to become completely disconnected from the physical quantities traded on the markets.

We cannot accept that, on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this may have, as it concerns the food of the world and humanity. And I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences. We need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scalewith Europe as a key playerwe reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, As in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is soaring on global markets,
we are only at 3% of the 2008 level.
The decline in production in certain traditional export zones due to climate change, the diversion of cereals for agrofuel production, and speculation.
The financial factors that amplified the upward effects are responsible for this situation, as shown in the reports of the IMF, the French authorities, and as also stated by the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis severely affect the 1.2 billion people worldwide living on less than $1.50 a day.
Since the month of October, an additional 44 million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
With two days until the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those approved in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of financial funds' positions on agricultural commodity markets.
This is the first step in countering the appetites of speculators.
The impact is dramatic for European breeders as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are in bankruptcy.
Five years ago, wheat was worth 100 euros per ton. Today, it is trading at nearly 300 euros.
The rules of the game have thus changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals. It would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of cereal stocks in producing countries to make them available to breeders at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, indexing the prices of meat paid to breeders on the evolution of feed prices.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aids intended to support cereals to animal productions. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Are we prepared in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a however.
The 2009-2010 H1N1 flu episode revealed that each Member State reacted on its own, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a shadow rapporteur on this file, I believe it was necessary to make these observations, but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens, who, it must be said, and this is indeed what seems most regrettable, have likely lost a bit of confidence in public health messages.

The report by Mrs Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and improved coordination with the...

European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an assessment of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
This is therefore a good report, and I congratulate the rapporteur. Obviously, it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain most of the competences in this area. It is, therefore, a genuine responsibility towards our citizens.
Thank you, Mr. President. It is my turn to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minorities, Mr. Bhatti.
This terrorist assassination follows numerous others targeting courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
And I think, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Ms. Sherry Raymond.
And I also wanted, once again, emphatically, to call on all the relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations with a view to
prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, with a clause upholding religious freedom and respect for human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, for the record, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit and the cumulative budget balance of central, local, and especially social security administrations was estimated at 32% of GDP in 2010.

If the Irish government, which is struggling to refinance itself through the markets, wishes to access loans from the Mechanism and the European Financial Stability Facility, it will have to meet social and fiscal reform obligations, even though these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is futile to blindly prescribe antipyretics without attempting to treat the underlying cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is incumbent upon that state to undertake a financial restructuring in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify its previous errors.
This austerity plan is expected to increase GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Just as an individual, a bank, without interfering in their private life and management, will condition its personal loan on a guarantee of solvency. Similarly, the European Union can lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

By adhering to the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the legal minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions, while not exempting itself from fiscal measures.
it is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity, which could dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but rather a protection of Eurozone stability through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, it is appropriate to assist Ireland, as well as other countries in distress, which also protects us, but not at any cost, especially not at the cost of seeing a state unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby jeopardizing its own citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us have said so just now, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
And each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
and 5 million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded without a viable alternative transportation solution.
And one year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is indeed scheduled for April 13 and 14, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, the ICAO, and IATA. However, it is crucial that EASA take on a genuine leadership role in coordinating safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse needs to be refined using more modern technological means.
These data, as seen last April, can however be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace, less driven by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the EASA is crucial in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond the information provided by the VACs, EASA must establish a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all relevant stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with EASA, to rapidly present concrete proposals that will fully contribute to the implementation of the European Single Sky.
President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
This is not a revolution. One cannot say that everything was wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
Nevertheless, it does present a number of significant advancements at this provisional stage of our work.
The main issues, in my opinion, concern better regulation of distance selling and, in particular, online sales. And this is Chapter 3. Because consumer rights in this area need to be strengthened.
E-commerce is highly beneficial. It expands consumer choice, enables them to secure the lowest prices, and also provides small and medium-sized businesses and artisans with new market opportunities.

To make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is, by focusing on a few specific points and establishing a complete harmonization of rights and responsibilities for all.

In very practical terms, it was necessary for an Italian customer buying on a Belgian website or a German website to know that henceforth they will benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its cooling-off period will be extended to 14 days across the entire Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without fear of an unpleasant surprise afterward.
This means that thanks to the double click, he will correctly verify his order.
Obviously, all this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are nuances in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, even though sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to adjust one's habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will need further improvement, and we will have to do so in the coming weeks, with the Council and the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already accomplished substantial work, thanks to our rapporteur Andrea Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this labor is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the European Union's internal market is very fragile.
It was necessary to have this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number 7, after the first paragraph, a first bullet point, ensure respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the freedom of the individual.
freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peaceful protest, as well as to listen to and address the legitimate demands of protesters, and to ensure their safety.

Thank you, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner. The open skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a stage. A stage that places Europe before a dilemma.
The transport committee and the committee itself have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.

Allow me, then, to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer. For the pilots, of whom I am one, find themselves faced with a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonize licenses across the European territory, will do so to the detriment of the 80,000 to 90,000 general aviation pilots.
directly affected, some holding only a single American license, and to the detriment, and this is significant, of businesses and jobs associated with this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security foundation.
There are 31 times fewer accidents among holders of American licenses.

The objectives of the basic regulatory text 216-2008 provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the benefits of which are not seen as requiring the delay of hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.

Therefore, I suggest a very open-sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I occasionally come to Parliament, piloting the plane myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our discussion, I will inevitably find myself repeating or reinforcing some of the points made earlier.
But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No Member State should be left alone to face the challenges it encounters, which, in my view, are faced by the entire European Union.
I am thus truly calling for the European Union's ability to organize itself and respond in a joint manner, in a spirit of solidarity.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
Over a year ago, a European pact on asylum and migration was adopted.
The time has come now, I believe, to outline this in a very concrete manner.
So we have indeed listened to Madame the Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations she made.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly emphasize certain aspects of his proposals.
Yes, at all costs, the resources of the Frontex agency must be strengthened.
It is necessary to strengthen the human, material, and financial resources of the Frontex agency, to enable it to provide more robust support to Operation Herms and Operation Poseidon.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for member states that are confronted, I would say, primarily, with the heightened migratory flows we are experiencing today.
And this will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we must forge closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, of course accompany them, assist them, and identify appropriate tools.
The Commissioner, I believe she went to Tunisia to discuss this, mentioned the mobility partnerships.
And yes, we must strengthen these instruments in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also with a precise and concrete mindset. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication have centered on the role of public services, services of general interest, within the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that encourages you to go beyond your Proposal 25, and we request that you exceed a mere proposal.

communications that do not meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders, users, and all those involved in public services, and that also do not align with the objectives you have otherwise outlined.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message regarding public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework, either a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with the legal foundations.
It is now up to you to translate them into legislative proposals.
I believe that Parliament is ready to support you in this direction.
Thank you, Mr. President. Well, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on this discharge. I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not solely an economic issue.

I am discussing this today in this chamber during the debate on the 2009 discharge because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Joint Parliamentary Budgetary Control Committee, Mr Mann, as a mere way to save money.
The issue of Parliament's expenditures also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest holding the group weeks in Strasbourg instead of Brussels. This would allow us to make better use of our Parliament seat in Strasbourg.
And since we aim to save costs, I suggest some additional measures. For instance, removing the Friday half-day for our colleagues. Also, abolishing half-days for journalists.
Europe is sufficiently attractive that one should not feel obligated to provide a per diem to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budgetary control, even though I welcome the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also hope to see the moralization and improvement of the compensation system for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it very ethical, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, in specie, on the day of the visit, without any work, without any oversight of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, as I indicate to you, the allocated sum exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for groups to send an estimate in advance to the visits service, for them to receive a deposit from Parliament for expenses, paid into a bank account, and for the balance to be paid on presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I acknowledge the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is an area that has continually expanded in recent years and now comprises 25 states, including three non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this light that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust among the States party to the Schengen Area is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
It should therefore be possible for other States to address this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly encouraged to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level, rather than intergovernmental.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the full range of long-term measures envisioned with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex, to provide more solidarity, I conclude, in order to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a gap in the Schengen area.
Just two more minutes, Madam President. Within a few weeks, migrants from countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant percentage of France's annual immigration.
This achievement is not static but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be adopted swiftly to ensure the public a better management of our Schengen area and thereby secure our common external borders. Thank you.
The European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any criticism of the Syrian regime's leadership.
