This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as indulgence, allowing them to intensify the situation.
repression. A repression so cruel that one cannot imagine for a moment that at the same time Syria could be elected to serve on the Human Rights Council of the United Nations Organization.
Even today, Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Deir ez-Zor, where terrible violence has been inflicted upon defenseless civilians.

Syria's presence on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its own people, in contempt of the very values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avert such a disaster?

Madame Mathieu, one minute and a half. Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Firstly, I would like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done exquisite work on this report, and God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders and have succeeded in doing so.
Whether it concerns police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea, and land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement this Schengen acquis in both technical and staffing terms.
Moreover, while no obstacles currently hinder this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be rigorously followed, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know, the mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full respect by these States of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
I fervently hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the exclusive circles formed by the Schengen States.
And we will all measure in this hemicycle the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President. In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the goal of making our economy greener and our transport systems more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have sought to empty the new Eurovignette directive proposal of its content and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to acknowledge Sad El Khadraoui here, and to the tenacity of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Admittedly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time the implementation of the polluter-pays principle and the internalization of external transport costs, such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this eurovignette to be more than just a tax, and to effectively contribute to the improvement of transport in Europe, member states are also encouraged to reinvest the collected funds in modernizing transport modes.
The Parliament has also managed to secure concrete inventions in the area of interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the policy objectives our institution has set for itself, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us at second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with farmers and countries that have joined us from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a significant step forward with this report.
It was not easy at first, and we were rather in a confrontational situation, but we reached a consensus, and that is what matters most.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have achieved this goal, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank Rapporteur Morciedes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of equality, justice, and equity among producers and among territories, and I believe this is important.
We have stated very clearly and confirmed the preservation and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms being indispensable for the quality and biodiversity of the regions.
I believe it was equally fundamental
The fact that this concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been incorporated into the texts is significant.
Now it will be necessary to implement this. It is a condition to make agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
you will need to respond clearly to this

Now, what we are expecting is that we will indeed enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate. Because beyond the texts and grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are heading. And that is what we are awaiting, of course, at this moment.
I would still like to end by uttering a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has resulted in a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was within the PAC budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are 80 million European citizens who are not properly fed.
Thank you, Mr. President. While the European Parliament can boast some significant progress in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, as we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be fully aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions around the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, and to European citizens.
The second observation pertains to the scope of this package.
By voting for what I wish, these six directives and regulations, we will undoubtedly take another step forward for the eurozone.
more towards a discipline that we have sorely lacked, a step, I say, no more, that will prove its usefulness in the future.
But it is enough to look at the fiery debates surrounding the overturned qualified majority to gauge the distance we still have to go. When it should be about rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority voting continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are contradictory.

Yes, states must also manage their budgets prudently, like a good father managing his household, but not through public spending stimulus. It is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks promise to be crucial, it is now a matter of reestablishing an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is highly significant for the advancement of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may well account for 25% of all commerce in Europe within 20 years, a figure that is quite considerable.
These purchases will be particularly cross-border.
They will enable consumers to expand their choices and also pay much less.
This is a genuine progress.
For SMEs and all artisans, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their market reach.

Among the key advancements, I would like to highlight two. The withdrawal period is extended to 14 days, and there is a summary of all information and the total price to be paid before finalizing the order.

And finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, along with all our colleagues, voted unanimously across all political groups, because on such a topic, what we needed was not polemics, but clearly an electoral consensus.
and we obtained it.

Mathieu Deminut. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to acknowledge the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very complex file, which required a high level of technical expertise, extensive work, and in-depth knowledge of the matter.
The control of our shared territory and European borders is one of the most significant challenges we must address, and technological tools are more than ever at the service of this endeavor.
Indeed, in recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some refer to as a "digital tsunami" is certainly expected to materialize in the coming years.
The SIS, the VIS, and the Rodax are all essential tools today to ensure the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring effective operational management of these databases is therefore a key issue for which it is our responsibility to provide an efficient solution.

This response is of course highly sensitive and Carlos Coelho had to overcome numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles. Despite this, he managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all interested parties.
The establishment of this network agency indeed appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enhance the management of existing information systems, provide better synergy between these databases, and additionally allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this matter was the location of the agency's headquarters. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have volunteered to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen information system in Strasbourg, for which it has been responsible for operational management and administration since 1995. Consequently, it has full technical control over the system.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wished to host this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise reached is excellent. A sort of division of tasks has taken place, Madam President, by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is well-balanced, and this understanding does not in any way compromise the centralized management of IT systems. Thank you, Madam President.
The cross-cutting social clause and Article 14 of the Treaty of Lisbon bindingly guarantee social rights, including the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Therefore, we must afford our social rights the full recognition they deserve within EU law, acknowledging the specific nature of SSIGs (Social and Solidarity-Based Initiatives) in relation to competition rules. These services have a strong local presence and are reliant on actors from the social economy.

Mr. De Rosa's report provides an opportunity to affirm the simple yet powerful and meaningful principles of equality, universality, and access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it is time to move to the practical aspects.
Yes, it is time to move towards concrete action. In this discussion, I therefore propose to genuinely support a European legislative instrument for social welfare services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green Group.
Thank you, Mr. President. Discussions regarding GMOs must imperatively be based on irrefutable arguments, both from a scientific and legal standpoint.
From a legal standpoint, member states wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory needed arguments that were as varied as they were strong.
The rapporteur expanded the range of possibilities, albeit with some reservations.
In terms of health, it's a bit more about health.
What is based on science must also be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the EFSA's scientific assessments, which are always positive about GMOs, unlike national scientific evaluations.

To restore trust, Commissioner, wouldn't it be necessary, as a first step, to simply apply the existing legislation aimed at providing significant scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remained a dead letter?
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Buzitil for the outstanding work he has achieved.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate him for it.
This report outlines an agency with enhanced capabilities, better aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex is finally being given the resources to fulfill its mandates.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and avail of the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly efficient.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of responsibilities enables us to address and consider migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than being limited to mere mechanical border management.
I approve of the possibility of sharing personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has fully asserted itself in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward in achieving a healthy and responsible management of our external borders, especially in the current context of persistent and intense migratory pressures. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank rapporteur Mr. Meyer and my colleagues for their sometimes critical remarks. But this 2010 activity report is indeed a valuable opportunity to discuss the Committee on Petitions, as it remains largely unknown.
Yet it is the Commission, with a direct, sometimes physical, link to the citizen, who can attend our debates in person.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament and a vast wealth of expertise due to her direct connection with citizens.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to the Parliament and defend their rights before the Committee on Petitions.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: attentive to its citizens' problems and united in finding solutions to protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of intervention and influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes nearly completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will be conducting a mission on this very subject in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always expedite the provision of all necessary information to us.
I would like to thank the European Commission for its research and verification work, even if sometimes it could go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
I finally appeal to the citizens. Continue to petition us as your directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness, as it is our responsibility to underscore the extreme urgency of the situation.
Firstly, we observe that what was a priority yesterday remains so today, even more so.

The lack of a definition and reliable statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting, given the crisis, that the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, called on Member States to end the problem of STIs by 2015.
Today, we have drawn a little closer to our goal.
Did the Member States actually make use of the year 2010 dedicated to the fight against poverty to concretely tackle this great precariousness whose urgency has become permanent?
I truly allow myself to doubt it, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy on homelessness, because of course there is misery and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious yet tailored approach is required, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their paths, and the disruptions in their lives.
This is a fundamental right, at the very least, from which a great many highly precarious individuals are excluded.
Thank you, Madam President. As everyone has stated in recent years, the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters. And the cities mentioned here would take up all the debate time.
I will still cite the AZF explosion, whose 10th anniversary we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been attempting to make this pooling of our efforts operational. And it is now time to act together and no longer wait for a new catastrophe to strike our territories before learning from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our physical, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding for the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for disaster prevention and response coordination.
And I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programmes that undeniably add value to Europe.

Here is the English translation:

I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it. It will thus open the way to European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
Over 43 million Europeans are at risk of food poverty.
The hour is grave.
Today, 6 Member States wish to end the food aid program without any replacement solution. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Indeed, there is a decision by the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, the Parliament called on you last July, at the initiative of our Green Group, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the program.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions. However, given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four-fifths.
The emergency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, food banks will be facing a shortage of over 300 million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in and fill this gap.
This is thus a real question of solidarity among peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible governing minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, as this is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our production methods to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest among us, who also have the right to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to avail themselves of this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union as of January.
Return to reason. Do we need food riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our approach?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, suddenly there is no one left. The Parliament delivered a strong message last time: human beings are more important than finance.
It is high time to reaffirm this.
In any case, we will remain very vigilant and will not fail to renew our constructive appeal.
Six member states hold the fate of 18 million needy Europeans in their hands.
six member states which claim to do no more or less than legalism
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm bells sounded by the associations that aid the most vulnerable?

And we, European Parliament members, representatives of all citizens, do we want an Europe where national selfishness sets the policies, paying little regard to the citizens of states in budgetary distress?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.
No. Let's maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but do not abandon those who, right now, in 2012, are counting on this support during a particularly difficult crisis. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Lige, ultimately resulting in hundreds of direct redundancies and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a native of Lige, I share the astonishment and despair of the 581 workers and their families who have been laid off.
but I also think of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited? Always the same. Poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, intense competition from imports from China and Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the shrinking of the automotive market, and finally, the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Lige site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this, and despite a challenging 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of 1,394,000,000 euros.
He paid 0 euros in taxes, which represents a tax rate of 0%.
This is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy practiced across multiple sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than an economic adjustment variable where human concerns are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable.
You spoke, Commissioner, of the rules?
Would it not be time for the Commission to develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational corporations?

For six years now, our Parliament has adopted a report concerning offshoring, corporate codes of conduct, subsidy repayment, and mandatory consultation between businesses, trade unions, and public authorities.
And since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission plan to do about this and within what timeframe?
While it is necessary to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, it is also essential to adopt a legislative framework.
a strong European approach to tackle delocalisations and restructurations and ensure full consideration of another form of capital, human capital.
Finally, regarding the Lige site, I hope it can benefit from the intervention of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to improve the situation of the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs hitting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as policymakers, have to play in the face of multinational corporations acting with impunity.

without any social ethics, which carries out stock market layoffs and offshores to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies at the expense of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of September 20th on the future of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, the Parliament clearly expressed its willingness to primarily support employees affected by the negative impacts of restructuring.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure coherence between GEF interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also advocated for the future FEMM regulation to include improvements so that FEMM does not produce the same outcomes it does today on multinational companies, with random and morally questionable effects, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look at the issue of structural funds and the Globalization Adjustment Fund separately without...
taking into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the mutual benefit ratio of a policy, I reiterate...
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Ombudsman brilliantly conducts investigations into complaints lodged against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is necessary to facilitate free movement, for our businesses and citizens alike, but it also serves as a powerful guarantee, especially against the critics of the Union, who all too often claim that the European Union is merely a bureaucratic machine devoid of control.
This is clearly nonsensical. Europe is doing genuine work on itself, thanks in particular to the European mediators.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission is under heavy criticism.
First, there are the figures. 65% is the actual figure, not 12% of the inquiries opened by the ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors. Many businesses come to us to express their frustration with the Commission, a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, on the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people find their way there.
And finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens that one comes across representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer questions from an MEP or who take refuge in bureaucratic language almost as well as politicians and wonder at citizens pleading their case.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative issues addressed and resolved by the ombudsman are Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by these concerns.
behavior. Citizens who are then negatively impacted by their confrontation with institutions, potentially fostering a sense of revolt, misunderstanding, and ultimately, Euroscepticism.

Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's topic is framed.
So we, the PPE group, offered our support to the report of our colleague Ms. Matt Larkin, a report to which we greatly contributed. Of course, we support those who have been affected.

The main recommendation of this report for increased professional mobility, greater simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications while ensuring patient safety and consumer protection.
But it is indeed in terms of the path to growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.
And indeed, the single market forum held in Krakow at the beginning of October did not err in this regard.

who recalled that Member States needed to recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation, and that they must act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of October 23rd last also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving growth, I quote, "smart, sustainable,"
including the implementation of the 12 priority proposals of the Act for the Single Market, the 12 proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications.

And we clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential contained within the internal market, our internal market of 500 million inhabitants, 500 million consumers.

Professional mobility should therefore not only ensure, if we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve the free movement of our fellow citizens within this market, but also, we hope, allow for additional growth margins to be acquired.
That is why, in particular, I wish to emphasize a practical recommendation: we, the PPE, specifically support the introduction of a voluntary professional card.
Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.
It is important that each year, the European Parliament takes stock of the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, insofar as
This Assembly plays a crucial role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year 2010 was a significant one for the APP, which convened twice, as previous speakers mentioned, in Spain and the DRC, to engage in exchanges focusing on, among other things,
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, or still on the freedom and independence of the media and food security.
But in 2010, the APP also sent its first election observation mission of this legislature.
I had the honour of co-chairing this mission in Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, a representative from Mali.
This election observation mission was an outright success.

We were able to meet with all the concerned political actors, and thanks to the dual origin of this delegation, which is both ACP (African, Caribbean, and Pacific Group of States) and European, we embodied a legitimacy distinct from European or African missions.
I invite the APP Bureau to repeat this experience, which allows us to put into practice the solidarity and special relationships that bind the European Union to the ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people living in precarious situations by 20 million by 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We must, now more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and at the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, in order to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must secure and optimize European funds, particularly the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently being maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at the horizontal level, and it is now time to act to enable the most disadvantaged to escape their precariousness.

And we, as policymakers, at the European, national, and local levels, must take the necessary measures to ensure them, without discrimination, access to housing, access to healthcare, access to justice, access to education, access to a first job with a minimum income, perhaps indexed according to each member state's poverty threshold.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, as well as in poverty reduction, will enable us to implement a sustainable, smart, and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we wish for and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Levin, for her excellent work.

As the draftsperson of the opinion for the Development Committee, I am pleased that the Fisheries Committee has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, as it is crucial that the development dimension be taken into account.
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing globally, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and enforcement by all states, including developing nations.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, the same constraints cannot be imposed, without accompanying measures, on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for instance, have very limited capacities.
Therefore, we must support their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
And this is why the Union must increase the financial envelope in favor of the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this field in developing countries.

Moreover, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing be implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources they could derive from fishing economic activity.
Now, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing its measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promotes the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the recipient states of aid.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to stem the scourge of illegal fishing. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to point out that, to a large extent, thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe. Therefore, the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy for the seas, oceans, and deep seas are essential for the future.
But I fear that with 20 or 50 million euros, it will not be sufficient to accomplish this great challenge.

Combating illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent at the European level to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly within the framework of international cooperation.
I also draw attention to the fact that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Runion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not mention it, I take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this specific issue.
Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I would like to acknowledge the Polish presidency for their dynamism and determination.

They will also have to seriously address the issue of reviving growth.

In saying this, we clearly see that today, financial stability has become the top priority, and the pressures, the tensions exerted from the outside on the countries of the eurozone, but also within the eurozone, are undermining our credibility and eroding trust.
And to hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, halt the terrible progression of national deficits and sovereign debts.
Financial stability has indeed become the top priority, an urgent obligation for all.

Our democracies have, in fact, all embarked on very courageous programs to sanitize their public finances and reduce their debts. But financial stability is also the prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
but whoever speaks of solidarity, whoever speaks of financial stability, budgetary discipline, because they go hand in hand, of course, must also speak of solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to undermine our democratic institutions.
Rather than contemplating the use of a judicial mechanism to punish in the event of budgetary drift, let us rather consider control and sanction mechanisms exercised by democratic institutions.

to say, the preservation of this common project and the safeguarding of the European Union. And in this movement to protect the euro, we must of course think about the future, think about the protection of future generations and the preservation of peace on our continent.

deficient or obsolete, all in the name of purely financial considerations, with each one expecting the neighbor or the supposed big American brother to make the efforts they are no longer willing to make themselves.

Madame Ashton, good day. Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution hinges on the implementation of the roadmap leading up to presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
In normal times, our contribution approximates 50% of this country's budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budget support for the 9th and 10th EDF programs, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population suffers and businesses operating in Madagascar are sometimes involuntarily called upon to contribute.

While supporting your position, we urge you to use your full influence with SADC to ensure that the legal and judicial imbroglio surrounding the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements in the implementation of this roadmap.

I would appreciate your opinion on this matter, and I also wish to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar Friendship Group, which we have just established in the European Parliament, is ready to work with you and the Commission in the interests of the Malagasy people and in defense of our Union's values.

Mr. President, dear colleague, I would like to quote the rapporteur, Mr. Iturguise, for the quality of his work, for the lengthy negotiation process he had to lead, and for the patience he demonstrated.

We finally come to the vote on this report, which is extremely important, as it allows us to bring the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens to this chamber, the Commission, and the Council.

Petitions concerning the environment are predominant, and waste is a significant concern among our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.
We consume without restraint.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely strengthened among citizens, clearly.
but this report is also a wake-up call for Member States.

A market worth 75 billion euros will inevitably attract covetousness.
States must send a strong signal
There should be increased penalties for companies that reveal public contracts for personal gain.
This report serves as a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of the waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one cooperates, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and cross-verification processes that could drag on for years.
Let us heed the petitioners' message and halt this mess more swiftly.
The Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he displayed before the Council and the Commission.

This agreement reminds me of that well-known illusion, recounted by children, of a paradise where vegetarian lions would eat grass alongside sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Ms. Fischer-Bowl has done everything in her power to ideologically destroy milk quotas.
In October 2009, the Court of Auditors nonetheless recognized the effectiveness of these milk quotas.

Now, today, we find ourselves in an even more dramatic situation, as we are witnessing in Denmark currently, where the most solid farms, due to increased production, are all facing bankruptcy, with a 40% drop in land prices.
Do we want this for the European level?
I say no, there needs to be a controlled approach to production with the involvement of public authorities. Thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ significantly from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our European minimal standards of protection, of which we avail ourselves, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data be processed lawfully and collected for specified, legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to enjoy a guaranteed right of access to and rectification of their personal data, as well as the right to initiate legal proceedings in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action is required to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a legal conflict that could be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must be intelligently articulated and coexist with international standards, as we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation resonates with other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism,
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and thus the protection of personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to prevent macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits, which threaten the European economy. However, this has not prevented social exclusion or the rise in unemployment.
It is time, in fact it is now urgent, that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States with a view to growth.

Each country will need to implement a national employment plan, which means that the focus should be on a wide range of topics such as, to name a few, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, and so forth.

Now, as Commissioner Andor reminded us earlier, we have 23 million unemployed people in Europe, but also 23 million SMEs and 23 billion euros in European funds dedicated to employment that are unused.
We could almost make this a 23-23 strategy.
And that's not including the 60 billion euros in unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on the principle of flexicurity.
So let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our overall social policy must be better adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those linked to unemployment, and active support for all socially virtuous enterprises.
We had poverty reduction targets to meet by 2020, yet we already know that these will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and appropriate measures taken by member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must be fully realized, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy expended on implementing robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Thank you, Madam President. Undeniably, the women's cause owes much to Europe.

Gender equality is indeed a fundamental value of our European project.
As a result, Europe has consistently worked in a very proactive manner for gender equality, for the cause of women's advancement.
Gradually, progress was made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, implemented, and directives established.
For many years now, there has been an extremely active and vigilant committee on women's rights and gender equality right here within our Parliament.
a European institute for gender equality has been established

However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains as relevant as ever, the struggle for gender equality and, in particular, for equal pay.
There is still an average pay gap of around 17% across all the countries of the European Union.
17% less: for equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, completely unacceptable.
The Women's Committee in the Parliament is currently working on a draft resolution to call on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on equal treatment.
which is one of the most concerning battles and lies at the heart of the worries and claims of European women in all our societies.

on global markets, and I think of the agricultural sector, for instance. The draft directive will have an impact, certainly differentiated according to the tax level of each member state, but an impact nonetheless on the price of diesel.

Instead, here we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in 9 European Union member states, which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in the face of declining steel demand.
