Thank you, Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Firstly, I wish to refute the unfounded allegations of the circulation in France of 500,000 to 1 million fake biometric passports that are said to be in circulation in our country.
France takes the risks of fraud concerning identity documents very seriously.
It does not treat offenses in the matter lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a fine of 15,000 euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, enabling prefectures to allocate additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud liaison officer is appointed.
Furthermore, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be cross-checked between administrative services, preferably via dematerialized means, in order to minimize the risk of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to supporting documents for proof of residence.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards enhanced security for proof of residence documents through the inclusion of a barcode.

The classic treatment of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents produced in previous title requests, and the possible authentication of supporting documents.

The secure issuance of titles is further guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant 1 at the time of filing the application and subsequently at the time of collecting the title, as well as by the taking of two fingerprints.
And this is without mentioning the enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen documents for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures.
Furthermore, France notifies international cooperation bodies, and in particular Interpol, of issued, lost, and stolen passports to prevent their fraudulent use.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, let's begin with an observation. Our fellow citizens are increasingly seeking and consuming locally produced and seasonal food, particularly for health and quality reasons.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and swiftly to this growing demand.

We must support the development of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining local slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous health controls, enable the growth of local short-supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and raise awareness among consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales on the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points, thereby offering local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission should facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct sales systems through delivery to consumers, such as the AMAP (Association for the Maintenance of Peasant Agriculture) model in France, which enables nearly 3,000 farmers to supply 60,000 families.
Finally, member states should be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning farm size, production volume, or the traditional nature of the product, to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I am pleased that this amending budget concerning ITER funding, which was adopted by a large majority in the Budgets Committee on March 29th, is now before us.
By funding this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic project in fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners in the Euratom community has called into question its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work, and the ITER project would have faced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people are working around the clock for ITER.
From 2015 until 2017-2018, the construction phase of the buildings and assembly of the machine could employ up to 4,000-5,000 people at this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision for the major environmental challenges facing us by 2020 and beyond.
This is why it is so important to launch a seventh environmental action program, by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and alignment between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
Fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, territorial planning, and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is affecting the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate realm.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially regarding the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco-design, recycling, and also environmental labeling of products in order to prevent waste and poor consumer choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental pedagogy, essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a political policy instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors, regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is undergoing today, the EU must reform its generalized system of preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial perspective, it is far from perfect. For we must keep in mind that this regulation is intended for developing countries.
In developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in support of the poorest countries,
This does not seem at all tenable at first glance.
To achieve this, the Commission has nonetheless developed a strictly accounting-based vision, relying solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
We clearly see the limitation of this approach.
What about the many middle-income developing countries with poorly diversified economies that are vulnerable to climate shocks?
The compromise reached with the Council does not address this issue, which is why I call on colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations across the various plans of the European Union is unfortunately not new.

This is, in my opinion, a crucial question. To that end, I have not only already submitted several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must adhere to the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the response from the European Commission, which stated that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and views may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
This is not an answer.
I am inquiring about the criteria that would enable us to measure the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented due to their availability in English alone, they fail in their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we wish to maintain written consultations as a tool underpinning the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must ensure democratic, transparent, and fair security for all citizens.
Therefore, if the European Commission opts for written consultation, it must take responsibility and provide the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

Additionally, the analysis should consider the overly short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulations aim to grant the European Commission increased powers to oversee national budgets and economic policies.

The rules are about to become stricter, and failing states will be mandated by the Brussels technocrats to implement budgetary cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balances.
This heightened surveillance is called a guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, spanked, one could say, with financial sanctions becoming stronger and more automatic.
Even if certain amendments aim to prevent solely budgetary austerity through growth measures, your proposals are merely there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And gradually, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, when the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Thank you, Mr. President. Without undermining the significance of the economic choices we must make, may I emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate?
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain European leaders, or those who consider themselves as such.
While everyone continues to advocate for economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that are finally worthy of the name, and this requirement even appears to be a sincere condition,
the absolute prerequisite for the survival of the eurozone, these gentlemen, once comfortably settled in their positions, deem it clever to criticize the balanced recommendations emanating from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst-case scenario, to turn public opinion against these "Brussels diktats," as they are called.
This irresponsible attitude might be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I'll be straightforward with you: our discussions on stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed focused on the economy.
unless the past mistakes regarding debt and public deficit come to an end and unless the member states' governments cease their reckless spending.
We are playing with fire right now.
European discipline must apply to all, without exception, including the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage, and our public opinions are ready for it, far more than some of their leaders are willing to believe.
And a final word to Madame Goulard, or I will have to show her the blue card. I would say, in conclusion, to Madame Goulard, in Redemption, there is Racha.

Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I would like to commend the determination of the European Commission and especially yours, Mr. Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the revival and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you recalled, Commissioner, it has already been more than two years that both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to pinpoint the challenges and sectors that require a deeper internal market. A deeper internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, and more employment.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually came to emphasize the full importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than continually seeking to invent new growth instruments, we are better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore take the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to the vote of our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States. More speed and efficiency in the transposition of already agreed directives.
Greater mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects. I will cite only one, that of strengthening worker mobility. Greater ease of movement, greater fluidity of circulation.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the Single Market Act that you will present after the summer.
We will know how to demonstrate both political willpower and the ability to apply pressure on member states. Thank you.
We witnessed the Mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the failings in European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, this 14-year fraud from 1996-2010, went unpunished,
These are 500,000 prostheses worn worldwide, 8,000 implant removals, and 48 confirmed cases of cancer.
There are now a staggering 3,500 complaints filed. This figure is both alarming and shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the American Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Mr. Commissioner, and the number of complaints and convictions for prosthesis failure filed in Great Britain, France in particular, were the national and European agencies able to overlook such a fraud?
This tragedy immediately led us to consider improving the European system for controlling medical devices, as you just explained.
We must, Commissioner, today construct a new system capable of preventing the scandal. But it is a new system that we must build.
This new legislation is scheduled for the fall, as you have indicated.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am, of course, satisfied with it.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as outlined in this resolution.
So, why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not advocate for the establishment of a market authorization for class 3 medical devices, which are the highest risk?
Commissioner Dali, could you please explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with a production increase of over 2.5%. At the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England, and across all European countries, prices are falling.
Which means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production, and we need to organize production volumes while also managing prices.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of a more than 44% increase in the price of plant proteins and a 30% increase in cereal prices.
The Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that the surplus value is shared among producers and that farmers are not victimized by businesses and large retailers.

So I am today asking the Commission, but also the Council, to reconsider the challenge to the control of production. But at the same time, I am saying very clearly that Member States must put their own houses in order, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
And this, too, is what led to these quotas being challenged.
So there is a dual responsibility, that of the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European railway area, this is a fine policy for European integration.
Here is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized for its failures, Europe, through this directive, finally points the way towards a major policy on sustainable transport and opens the field for a significant railway investment policy for employment.

I welcome the key measures adopted in the organization of the rail network, the establishment of national regulators in each member state, and the creation of a five-year multi-annual investment contract, thereby setting out the organization's funding commitments.

railway infrastructures, but also, I am pleased with the establishment of financial flow transparency between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder about non-discriminatory access to certain

And finally, I welcome the confirmation sought by European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front. For instance, the absence of a reference to minimum service, as well as to full unbundling between the NRGEC and the operator.

but allow me to raise a requirement that we cease to consider, particularly from the European Commission, the liberalization of the rail sector as the only strategic horizon for the development of a single rail area. Instead, let us decide on a European strategy for integrated investment that supports employment in Europe.
Similarly, I would like, to conclude, to ask you a question, Commissioner Callas.
three days after the European Council of June 28th and 29th, following the validation of a 120 billion growth pact to boost the European economy,
specifically through investment in infrastructure. Can you tell us, Commissioner, what amount is the European rail sector likely to benefit from under this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but tonight I would like to address a question that is certainly peripheral, but extremely important to this topic.
These are the remarks made by Commissioner Mr. De Guth at the International Trade Committee on Wednesday, June 20th.

I tell you, if you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me assure you that the Commission will nonetheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the procedure before the Court of Justice.

Not only do these statements, in my view, misrepresent the treaties, but more importantly, and this is what I wish to highlight, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, democracy in general, and the citizens we represent.
Here, at a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President.
Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Through your obstinacy and procedural tactics, you have enabled us to demonstrate the significance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for inspiring hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and 2.8 million to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is played out here, that European elected officials are the people's representatives, their representatives.
Thank you once again for the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I greet them. It's a breath of fresh air in our institutions, too often perceived as technocratic.
Thank you, Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, the one of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like to thank you tomorrow as well for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your work method.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I speak on behalf of Maurice Pongard, the Development Committee's draftsperson for opinion on Mr. Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to reiterate that the European Union, when it wishes to sanction a country that engages in unsustainable fishing, must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence for development, I believe it is crucial that the measures adopted on fishing do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, and for the level of development and vulnerability of countries to be duly taken into account. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea plunderers, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim, by lumping together all categories of fishing.

It is understood that fish stocks must be preserved, but we must also enable our fisherman to make a living from their activity and protect the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Yet the main measures of the European executive once again go in the direction of reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, which would ensure the industrialization and concentration of the sector, as well as a complete ban on discards, which professionals deem unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but in its current state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, on this challenging report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral energy negotiations between European countries and third states.
The agreement reached in trilogue will enable the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and in the interest of pragmatism, this can only be welcomed.
Europe's energy sector is advancing, certainly not fast enough, but it is making progress.
As a major energy importer, the European Union finds itself structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to foster a more European perspective on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to more widely disseminate information on energy agreements within the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will thus enhance transparency in the energy market and enable the anticipation of energy supply issues.
I am pleased that this decision does not create an obligation with regard to agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes involved in competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to safeguard the interests of our businesses and the rules protecting private contracts.
Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this file.

It was necessary because we were starting from a long way back with the Commission's basic proposal. No specific mention of the outermost regions, directly affected by competition from Latin American countries. No automatic trigger.

from the stabilization mechanism, no possibility for our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as potential sources of fair and competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote endorses the progress made on these points in the International Trade Committee.
Despite everything, it is not sufficient, because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they render these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Moreover, the Commission must allocate an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions that already have record-high unemployment rates.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, first of all, I would like to thank Charles Gorenz for his excellent report.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as we approach the 2015 deadline for the MDGs, even though some targets seem
affected, we must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with short- and medium-term timelines.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rising power of emerging countries, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities. Priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we need to rethink European and international institutional systems regarding environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that effectively make decisions, such as the WTO, for instance.
Finally and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not merely a matter of charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better consider the geostrategic shifts of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, still developing nations.
Henceforth, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups, as well as those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development, and above all, of responsible development.
Thank you, Mr. President. The agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my view, raises many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission intends that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the sole criterion of per capita wealth.
Now, as Mrs Ashton reminded us, these issues are not merely a matter of accounting, but warrant a genuine political debate on defining our priorities in international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach, in my view, is not in keeping with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, let us applaud the initiative taken by Jacques Delors 20 years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall fell.
And despite this, despite all the progress we have witnessed since the start of our debate, it is clear that the single act today is synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
So I would like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build together a fairer Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

And there are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your views on these avenues, which are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it, including tax harmonization and public services.
protector, minimum wage in Europe, implementation of enhanced cooperations, job-creating, facilitating cross-border cooperations and developing a fair trade policy.
These, I believe, are the challenges that lie before us, 20 years on.
And I am counting on you, Commissioner, for us to carry together this fine policy of European construction.

Thank you, Mr. President. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have been closely following the report by my colleague Regina Bastos on the 20 main concerns of citizens and businesses.
We discussed this report, incidentally, in connection with our debate on the 20th anniversary of the internal market.
For 20 years already, the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital is supposed to be fully realized within our living space, our area of exchange, our internal market.

I was particularly interested to note that at the forefront of concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens are the licenses for professional qualifications, and that we truly need to be especially proactive and highly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens are expecting in order to truly establish, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are much faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
This is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group on this topic, the modernization of these procedures, I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to genuinely address this major challenge of mobility.
more mobility for more Europe. That is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
The Petitions Committee has acquired the right this year to be automatically associated for the hearing of European Citizens' Initiatives.
This is, for me, the strong signal of the year 2011 for this commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in cases of breach of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can increasingly be seen as the citizens' privileged interlocutor in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the outcomes of the Petitions Committee's positions.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal entanglements on which we would like to take a stance. But while the issues are European,
Solutions should be European, but we remain powerless as subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will use the challenging example of transnational divorces. The issues are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case, those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties for many parents in seeing their children born of binational unions, we remain in Parliament still powerless to act.

My proposal that all European citizens have the right to a national ombudsman, especially given the large number of petitions coming from Germany, based on the model of the Defender of Rights in France, has had no effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, it remains a solution that reconciles the European problem with the national solution.
In many cases, European law appears powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizenship in 2013 must address citizens' grievances, the costs of forces, but we need means to act in order to be.
